revision.comment: /* dog-ape - not aplicable for all animal species */
revision.text: == From the 1913 dictionary == Dog \Dog\ (d[o^]g), n. [AS. docga; akin to D. dog mastiff, Dan. dogge, Sw. dogg.] 1. (Zo["o]l.) A quadruped of the genus Canis, esp. the domestic dog (C. familiaris). Note: The dog is distinguished above all others of the inferior animals for intelligence, docility, and attachment to man. There are numerous carefully bred varieties, as the beagle, bloodhound, bulldog, coachdog, collie, Danish dog, foxhound, greyhound, mastiff, pointer, poodle, St. Bernard, setter, spaniel, spitz dog, terrier, etc. There are also many mixed breeds, and partially domesticated varieties, as well as wild dogs, like the dingo and dhole. (See these names in the Vocabulary.) 2. A mean, worthless fellow; a wretch. What is thy servant, which is but a dog, that he should do this great thing? -- 2 Kings viii. 13 (Rev. Ver. ) 3. A fellow; -- used humorously or contemptuously; as, a sly dog; a lazy dog. [Colloq.] 4. (Astron.) One of the two constellations, Canis Major and Canis Minor, or the Greater Dog and the Lesser Dog. Canis Major contains the Dog Star (Sirius). 5. An iron for holding wood in a fireplace; a firedog; an andiron. 6. (Mech.) (a) A grappling iron, with a claw or claws, for fastening into wood or other heavy articles, for the purpose of raising or moving them. (b) An iron with fangs fastening a log in a saw pit, or on the carriage of a sawmill. (c) A piece in machinery acting as a catch or clutch; especially, the carrier of a lathe, also, an adjustable stop to change motion, as in a machine tool. Note: Dog is used adjectively or in composition, commonly in the sense of relating to, or characteristic of, a dog. It is also used to denote a male; as, dog fox or g-fox, a male fox; dog otter or dog-otter, dog wolf, etc.; -- also to denote a thing of cheap or mean quality; as, dog Latin. Dog \Dog\, v. t. [imp. & p. p. Dogged; p. pr. & vb. n. Dogging.] To hunt or track like a hound; to follow insidiously or indefatigably; to chase with a dog or dogs; to worry, as if by dogs; to hound with importunity. I have been pursued, dogged, and waylaid. -- Pope. Your sins will dog you, pursue you. --Burroughs. Eager ill-bred petitioners, who do not so properly supplicate as hunt the person whom they address to, dogging him from place to place, till they even extort an answer to their rude requests. -- South. {{unsigned|Maveric149|22:34, 12 December 2002 (UTC)}} == 'dog' and pronunciation mergers == (Hippietrail commented: should this be kAt/kOt merger or the usual kQt/kOt merger?) :About that: :*commonwealth English has three vowels /Q/ /O:/ and /A:/, and in this word /dQg/. :*There are two major kinds of American dialects as far as this is concerned; one is more regionally marked (and apparently on the way out), merging /Q/ into /O/, thus having /O/ and /A/ (length not being distinctive in rhotic America) — in which case this would be /dOg/. :*The most unmarked kind of American merges that /O/ into /A/ except sometimes before /r/ (forage /"fOr@dZ/ but borrow /"bAroU/), and thus would have /dAg/. :The [[w:cot-caught merger]], apparently, refers to these two American dialects, and does not appear to involve [Q] at all, so yeah, ''ɑ-ɔ merger'' is correct. —[[User:Muke|Muke Tever]] 04:52, 16 Jun 2004 (UTC) :Please use IPA! No one can understand your transcription and you don't mention which system you are using. --[[Special:Contributions/2.245.96.130|2.245.96.130]] 10:35, 6 October 2016 (UTC) == "adopted by many Continental languages" == Which languages would that be? --[[User:Jcmo|Jcmo]] 09:25, 31 March 2008 (UTC) :For example, Russian [[дог]], French [[dogue]], German [[Dogge]], Spanish [[dogo]], Frisian [[dogge]]. [[User:Stephen G. Brown|—Stephen]] 13:21, 1 April 2008 (UTC) :::I see the point. When I first read it, I took it to mean that it was adopted as a general word for dog, not for a specific type of dog. Thanks. --[[User:Jcmo|Jcmo]] 14:26, 1 April 2008 (UTC) == Where/how to add examples of definition 6? == The mechanical part that moves fabric under a sewing-machine needle is the [[feed-dog]]. A steel rod, sharpened on both ends and bent at angles, that holds logs during log-house construction is a [[log dog]]. Where and how do I enter these interesting uses of [[dog]] as a holding device? [[User:Jane Elderfield]] {{unsigned|Jane Elderfield|21:28, 24 August 2008 (UTC)}} :Do it the same way you see for definition 5, "You dirty dog." [[User:Stephen G. Brown|—Stephen]] 21:42, 24 August 2008 (UTC) :Definition 7 seems to be just a justification for def. 6 [[User:John1deer|John1deer]] 20:59, 21 February 2009 (UTC) == Foot or feet? == People call their feet dogs - should that be in the article? -[[User:Kslays|kslays]] 19:35, 19 February 2010 (UTC) : I've never heard of it, but yes, if it's real. Perhaps it should be marked as slang. [[User:Equinox|Equinox]] [[User_talk:Equinox|◑]] 19:37, 19 February 2010 (UTC) ::Oops, it's already listed under [[dogs]]. Should there be a link in this page, even though the feet meaning is only used when plural? Probably not I guess. -[[User:Kslays|kslays]] 21:07, 25 February 2010 (UTC) :::I've heard people say that. I've never heard someone call one foot a dog. Hmmm.... it could be hands=hounds and feet=dogs. Well maybe not. [[User:Redddogg|Redddogg]] 13:25, 5 June 2010 (UTC) ::::Yes, it’s only used in the plural. My dogs are barking = my feet hurt. Nobody would say, "he stepped on my right dog", meaning "my right foot". [[User:Stephen G. Brown|—Stephen]] 06:08, 7 June 2010 (UTC) :::::Should we take it off this entry then, if it's already on [[dogs]]? [[User:Redddogg|Redddogg]] 13:02, 7 June 2010 (UTC) :::::It is not used ''only'' in the plural. It would be possible to attest to the rare singular use. [[User: DCDuring |DCDuring]] [[User talk: DCDuring|TALK]] 14:21, 7 June 2010 (UTC) ::::::I think it has to be addressed in some way also at [[dog]], because most people who want to look up the noun in "my dogs are barking" would probably first reduce it to the singular. [[User:Stephen G. Brown|—Stephen]] 14:21, 7 June 2010 (UTC) :::::::Then no problem by me. I don't think it does any harm to mention it here. [[User:Redddogg|Redddogg]] 21:14, 7 June 2010 (UTC) : Is there a citation for this? I've also never heard of it. Could be be regional? We certainly don't say it in California. --[[User:RobertGary1|RobertGary1]] ([[User talk:RobertGary1|talk]]) 17:56, 22 May 2015 (UTC) ::It's probably dated rather than regional. My father said it, not me. I'm retired. [[User: DCDuring |DCDuring]] [[User talk: DCDuring|TALK]] 19:19, 22 May 2015 (UTC) :::[https://www.google.com/search?num=30&safe=off&client=firefox-a&hs=KvZ&rls=org.mozilla%3Aen-US%3Aofficial&channel=sb&q=site%3Agoogle.com%2Fnewspapers+%22dogs+ache%22+OR+%22dogs+are+aching%22+OR+%22dogs+were+aching%22+OR+%22dogs+ached%22&oq=site%3Agoogle.com%2Fnewspapers+%22dogs+ache%22+OR+%22dogs+are+aching%22+OR+%22dogs+were+aching%22+OR+%22dogs+ached%22&gs_l=serp.3...5805.7648.0.10166.2.2.0.0.0.0.107.174.1j1.2.0.ekpsrh...0...1.1.64.serp..2.0.0.i9lS9cz-jpY This Google News search] suggests that it is dated, but it can be found in contemporary fictional dialog at Google Books. [[User: DCDuring |DCDuring]] [[User talk: DCDuring|TALK]] 19:29, 22 May 2015 (UTC) ==Coward?== Is meaning 5, coward, really a distinct meaning? The example given could be for meaning 4, any man, or meaning 6, a contemptible person. I've never heard of "dog" especially meaning coward. Dogs can be quite couragous, if they have a reason to be. [[User:Redddogg|Redddogg]] 05:30, 5 June 2010 (UTC) :Your last sentence is so ridiculous. There are both cowardly dogs and courageous dogs, but you can't just object to this because you don't like it. Why are female dogs prostitutes? The next thing you'd write would be "female dogs are not prostitutes, so they cannot be called 'bitches'". This is semantics. It all goes down to how people use it. --[[Special:Contributions/2.245.190.230|2.245.190.230]] 19:25, 10 October 2016 (UTC) ==Dog family== The domestic dog is actually a subspecies of the gray wolf, or common wolf as the article says. There is also the "dog family" which includes foxes, jackels, etc. Also some members are called dogs, for instance the African hunting dog and the racoon dog. [[User:Redddogg|Redddogg]] 13:23, 5 June 2010 (UTC) :That doesn't make any sense. If the domestic dog was already a subspecies, how do you technically call the different breeds? There is no such thing as "dog family", it's "Canidae". --[[Special:Contributions/2.245.190.230|2.245.190.230]] 19:06, 10 October 2016 (UTC) ==RFV== {{archive-top|rfv|failed}} There's plenty of jokes using the fact that dog and god are reverses of each other, but not that particularly amount to a new meaning. The example sentence works against the sense, since a quick Google books search reveals that "Dog is my co-pilot" is the title of at least two books, one published by ''The Bark'' magazine, subtitled "Great Writers on the World's Oldest Friendship", and one (sans hyphen) subtitled "Stories From the War on Mailmen". Another book refers to T-shirts that say "Love me, love my dog" and "of course" "Dog is my co-pilot". One section titled "Dog is my co-pilot" says "My friend Jane and I are always looking for places to substitute Dog for God. We don't mean to offend anyone, so sorry if it hits a nerve. It just makes us both smile to picture our dogs in the passenger seat of the..." The closest thing I find is the old joke about the dyslexic agnostic wondering if there's a dog, even that's not this sense.--[[User:Prosfilaes|Prosfilaes]] 17:22, 17 January 2011 (UTC) :Which sense are you challenging? Or is this for [[WT:TR]]. [[User: DCDuring |DCDuring]] [[User talk: DCDuring|TALK]] 18:36, 17 January 2011 (UTC) :: "(humorous) Not god".--[[User:Prosfilaes|Prosfilaes]] 19:01, 17 January 2011 (UTC) :::Sorry. I missed Ety 2. As a cynolater myself, I find this definition offensive. Furthermore, saying that {{m|en|dog}} means "god" doesn't agree with my definitionnotion of "meaning". [[User: DCDuring |DCDuring]] [[User talk: DCDuring|TALK]] 19:45, 17 January 2011 (UTC) : '''Failed RFV'''. [[User:Equinox|Equinox]] [[User_talk:Equinox|◑]] 01:12, 9 July 2011 (UTC) {{archive-bottom}} == "and was adopted by many continental European languages." (2) == I looked into the translation table and found nearly no language adopted this word. This phrase should be written out more detailly. {{unsigned|2.245.34.142|10:51, 5 October 2013 (UTC)}} *"many" => "several". Also see the 2008 discussion above. [[User:SemperBlotto|SemperBlotto]] ([[User talk:SemperBlotto|talk]]) 10:56, 5 October 2013 (UTC) == [[Wiktionary:Requests for verification|RFV]] discussion: July 2015–February 2016 == {{archive-top|rfv|failed|link=Special:PermanentLink/37125259#dog}} {{fake==|1=[[dog]]}} I question the validity of the last verb sense, "(intransitive, with up) To position oneself on all fours, after the manner of a dog." -- I have never heard of it, can't verify it or find any uses. Urbandictionary doesn't list it (has a different meaning for [http://www.urbandictionary.com/define.php?term=dogged%20up dogged up]). "dogged up on the ground" and "dogged up on the floor" don't get anything. If it does exist, it seems like it should be moved to [[dog up]] anyway. [[User:WurdSnatcher|WurdSnatcher]] ([[User talk:WurdSnatcher|talk]]) 23:09, 8 July 2015 (UTC) I can't find that meaning for "dog up", -- although I find a number of others. Primarily to dress in one's best clothes, but also to move doggedly. [[User:Kiwima|Kiwima]] ([[User talk:Kiwima|talk]]) 01:12, 20 July 2015 (UTC) :Yeah, I made [[dogged up]], [[all dogged up]] when I was looking it up, didn't find any real good citations of the general verb [[dog up]] though. [[User:WurdSnatcher|WurdSnatcher]] ([[User talk:WurdSnatcher|talk]]) 17:36, 14 September 2015 (UTC) :: The example sentence seems to use 'be dogged up' rather than an intransitive verb 'dog up', which would be more like "why are you dogging up in the middle of the room" (as opposed to being dogged up). [[User:Renard Migrant|Renard Migrant]] ([[User talk:Renard Migrant|talk]]) 20:54, 14 September 2015 (UTC) :'''RFV-failed.''' [[User:-sche|- -sche]] [[User talk:-sche|(discuss)]] 02:56, 2 February 2016 (UTC) {{archive-bottom}} == dog-ape == This occurs in Shakespeare (only?), apparently meaning a male ape. However, our male animal sense only mentions wolves and foxes. Chambers 1908 gives ''dog'' as a general-purpose ''adjective'' (!) for male animals. [[User:Equinox|Equinox]] [[User_talk:Equinox|◑]] 01:39, 9 April 2019 (UTC) :That - about "a general-purpose ''adjective'' (!) for male animals." is very much unexpected. It may be Chambers 1908 was misunderstood, or has been lenient with his definition, but I cant't check at the source now. :It may had been meant to advise "dog" use for indicating male animal of mamalian predator species, or of smaller types of mamalian species. I have never encountered it used as dog-spider, dog bee (for a drone), dog ant; and also not a dog crocodile or dog aligator. I also had not encountered it used yet for males from bovine species, elephants and several other big plantivores (there bull, or ox when aproprite, seem to be in use). :'''Conclusion''': dog for a male of animal species, at best as possible use, and detected with some speces of animals, not for general use (for most, or all animals). --[[User:Marjan Tomki SI|Marjan Tomki SI]] ([[User talk:Marjan Tomki SI|talk]]) 20:37, 29 June 2021 (UTC) == Etymology == The best etymology (and considerably better than mine which would have been morphologically incorrect as to a relation with Ancient Greek 'DAKNO' (to bite)); is the earlier one that ought to be included: + Dog is from "[[docga]]", perhaps from {{der|en|gem-pro|*dukkǭ||t=power, strength, muscle}} + diminutive suffix {{m|ang|-ga}}, probably meaning "little dynamo" in the original sense. If so, cognate with Old English {{m|ang|-docce||muscle}}; compare {{m|ang|fingerdocce||finger-muscle}}. --> Andrew H. Gray 11:43, 11 April 2020 (UTC)[[User:Werdna Yrneh Yarg|Andrew]] ([[User talk:Werdna Yrneh Yarg|talk]]) == a useless item == my boss once referred to a severely outdated computer peripheral that we were expected to sell at full price as a dog. Maybe she made it up on the spot, since the context was clear, but maybe this word has yet another sense that just isn t used that much. [[user:Soap|—]][[user talk:Soap|Soap]][[Special:Contributions/Soap|—]] 22:28, 28 May 2020 (UTC) : {{reply to|Soap}} Green's ''Newspeak'' (1984) defines ''dog'' as a racehorse that is slow or difficult to handle. I think I've also heard it used for bad or slow cars, e.g. "that Skoda is such a dog". So yes, we may be missing a sense. [[User:Equinox|Equinox]] [[User_talk:Equinox|◑]] 17:30, 14 April 2021 (UTC) ::I've added a sense "Something that performs poorly" and made the "slang" film sense a subsense of it. [[User:DCDuring|DCDuring]] ([[User talk:DCDuring|talk]]) 21:58, 16 April 2021 (UTC)

revision.comment: Reverted edits by [[Special:Contributions/MEMZAT13|MEMZAT13]]. If you think this rollback is in error, please leave a message on my [[User talk:Surjection|talk page]].
revision.text: __TOC__ == Miscellaneous comments == Regarding translations for this word, several of the languages in the list to not use articles at all. It would be better to indicate this instead of presuming that one will be found. [[User:Eclecticology|Eclecticology]] 15:44 Apr 11, 2003 (UTC) ---- This page is in desperate need of a clean-up. I have added it to the cleanup page. Does Vietnamese have its own alphabet? If this is just the Latin alphabet, then there is no point in having a Vietnamese entry saying that A is the first letter. — [[User:Paul G|Paul G]] 15:48, 5 Jul 2004 (UTC) :Vietnamese does have its own alphabet which, like English, is derived from but not "just" the Latin alphabet. It has 5 extra letters which are not used in English including one or two which are used in some European languages. It also 4 or 5 diacritics which are drawn above or below the vowel letters to designate tones. — [[User:Hippietrail|Hippietrail]] 11:02, 7 Jul 2004 (UTC) ---- I've removed the bolloks about articles being adjectives. But the format or choice of headings is still not good. For instance it's difficult to find the right place to put the synonyms/alternative spelling "an", and the "see also" to "the" and "one". — [[User:Hippietrail|Hippietrail]] 01:50, 7 Sep 2004 (UTC) ---- It could still use a good bollocking. It's on my hit list. -[[User:Dmh|dmh]] 04:19, 15 Sep 2004 (UTC) ---- I've added a generic sense of ranking on a scale denoted by letters, but the specific sense of letter grade should stay. It's idiomatic enough (at least throughout the US) that when someone says "I got a D." it's immediately clear that they are referring to a course or exam, and that ''D'' is the lowest of the four passing grades. If this definition were missing, someone familiar with English but not with this particular system could miss these connotations. -[[User:Dmh|dmh]] 02:46, 20 Sep 2004 (UTC) ---- Was the last change by 212.179.235.102 in the Latin entry; ablative case -> procrastinative case valid? I think not. — [[User:Hippietrail|Hippietrail]] 11:09, 4 Nov 2004 (UTC) ---- An anonymous user decided to treat the indefinite article sense as its own entity and provide an incomplete description of the alternation with [[an]]. The entry for [[an]] has a much more complete account, and there is no point in duplication. If there's any doubt that ''an'' is primary, consider the etymology (originally from Anglo-Saxon, cognate with ''one'', ''unum'', ''een'' etc.) and that there are plenty of examples of consonants being dropped in commonly-used form (''o'clock'' for example) and few if any of a consonant being randomly added. -[[User:Dmh|dmh]] 15:58, 12 Apr 2005 (UTC) == Part of speech == Should this be listed as ===Article=== and further qualified on the definition lines? --[[User:Connel MacKenzie|Connel MacKenzie]] [[User talk:Connel MacKenzie#|T]] [[Special:Contributions/Connel MacKenzie|C]] 19:29, 28 November 2005 (UTC) == Gregg Shorthand Spelling == There are different wiki-definitions for capital A and lowercase a. It looks like the lowercase a is defined as an indefinite article, the capital as a noun or symbol, e.g. - Exam grade of A, or blood type A. Wouldn't a capital A used as a noun usually be spelled in Gregg as a, rather than [dot]? --[[User:Frank N Stein|Frank N Stein]] 14:38, 6 February 2006 (UTC) The [dot] is merely an outline for the indefinite articles 'a' and 'an.' The large ellipse stands in for three different vowels that are written differently in traditional English longhand. They can be distinguished, if need be, by writing a dot or check beneath the vowel; however, this is typically unnecessary. -- Anon, 3:00 GMT, 6 March 2006 {{unsigned|24.181.235.24|03:01, 7 March 2006 (UTC)}} == "A" and project Gutenberg == The word "A" is NOT the 5th most common word used in the English language, according to the Project Gutenberg list from 4/16/2006. It is closer to 80. [http://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Wiktionary:Frequency_lists/PG/2006/04/1-10000] The list that the editor was referring to was the one from TV and movie scripts. [http://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Wiktionary:Frequency_lists/TV/2006/1-1000] Kyle[[User:65.94.125.201|65.94.125.201]] 07:31, 16 November 2006 (UTC) : I've received a fair amount of criticism for my analysis (ongoing) or the Project Gutenberg texts. Particularly, the {{temp|rank}} was at one time, deemed to be of such insignificant lexical value that it was proposed for removal/deletion. : I never did automate the refreshing of the rankings, from the updated lists. If I neglect it much longer (another year), the rank template may get obliterated, I fear. As expected, the rankings are gradually diverging from the "latest" runs where I re-rank them (including newer texts as they appear on Project Gutenberg.) I'm really unsure how to proceed. I haven't exactly boxed myself in by adding the 'rank' template to the top 1,000...but I do appreciate the complaints better now. That is, that the three more and less common terms, have no lexical relation, therefore should be downplayed, instead of glorified prominently. : I do think the differences between the P.G. and the TV scripts are quite fascinating. : --[[User:Connel MacKenzie|Connel MacKenzie]] 07:44, 16 November 2006 (UTC) == My Humble Opinion == These discussion pages are like superarticles filled with links and linebreaks! O_O {{unsigned|STUFF2o|19:48, 8 April 2007 (UTC)}} == very complex == ...it's just "a" or "an", and the letter, why so much (useless?) information?--[[User:Esteban.barahona|Esteban.barahona]] 03:12, 27 August 2008 (UTC) :Because it's really more than that in English. In English, ''a'' can function as an article, a preposition, or a verb. It's also a word in many, many other languages, so that information is also included. In Galician (galego), for example, ''a'' is an article, preposition, and a pronoun. --[[User:EncycloPetey|EncycloPetey]] 03:18, 27 August 2008 (UTC) == Just busy == I had added the rfc tag saying the entry was hideous. I think we have made good progress. It just looks too busy now. Further improvement would require some innovation (like Visviva's gallery experiment), making better use of the thumb image at the top right, or moving material off the page, perhaps to an appendix. Are all of the elements in Translingual strictly translingual? It is beginning to look like a translation table, not properly labeled as such. [[User: DCDuring |DCDuring]] [[User talk: DCDuring|TALK]] 19:46, 22 October 2009 (UTC) == "a (indefinite)" == "2.One certain or particular [entity]. We've received an interesting letter from a Mrs. Miggins of London" It seems contradictory to have this definition ("certain or particular") under the heading of "indefinite". Given the assumption that there may be more than one Mrs. Miggins in London and that we don't know which "Mrs. Miggins of London" wrote the letter, how is that any more "certain or particular" than saying that the letter is from "a woman", which is clearly not certain or particular. This example works better in Merriam-Webster's 11th Collegiate Dictionary: "['a' is] used as a function word before a proper noun to indicate limited knowledge about the referent: *a Mr. Smith called to inquire about the job*". [[Special:Contributions/75.21.22.106|75.21.22.106]] 15:34, 6 December 2009 (UTC) ==Modern/Slang Usages== I'm not a native speaker but it seems to me that "a" has also more modern usages, such as: 1. A way to say "Correct!" (that's an A!) 2. An euphemism for "ass" 3. Something I cannot perfectly identify, but only seems to have a emphatic function, like when Brad Pitt says in /Inglorious Basterds/: "Cousin, business is a-boomin!" As I have no precise idea of how colloquial those usages are, I won't add them to the article, but maybe they should be considered (and I'd appreciate any further information). [[User:Irakos5|Irakos5]] 15:28, 5 August 2010 (UTC) :As a partial reply... :1 You'll find that sense under [[A]], since the capitalized form has different meanings. :3 That's [[a-]], under Etymology 3. :--[[User:EncycloPetey|EncycloPetey]] 00:01, 6 August 2010 (UTC) ==RFV discussion== {{archive-top|rfv|archived}} Rfv-sense: In Quebec French, "her". I don't read a lot of Quebec French, but I know some Quebeckers and I've never heard of this. Surely she has would become "a a" which is just silly. [[User:Mglovesfun|Mglovesfun]] ([[User talk:Mglovesfun|talk]]) 15:42, 9 December 2010 (UTC) : '''Keep.''' This sense was added by a native and trustworthy speaker of Quebec French, namely {{user|Circeus}}, in [http://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/a?diff=6847906 this edit]. Normally I'd say sure, ask for cites, but in this case it's basically impossible to search for, so . . . {{temp|rfquote-sense}}? : By the way, just because "a" is a form of "elle" doesn't mean that it appears in all contexts (perhaps "pour a" is legal but "a a" is not); but even if it does, I don't see that "a a" is any sillier than "a à" ("has to"). : —[[User: Ruakh |Ruakh]][[User talk: Ruakh |TALK]] 16:23, 9 December 2010 (UTC) ::Agreed, request speedy keep. [[User:Mglovesfun|Mglovesfun]] ([[User talk:Mglovesfun|talk]]) 17:38, 9 December 2010 (UTC) '''Kept''' as a withdrawn request. {{rfquote-sense}} added.​—[[User:Msh210|msh210]]℠ ([[user talk:Msh210|talk]]) 18:12, 9 December 2010 (UTC) {{archive-bottom}} ==Etymology 4: "Shoulda"== Etymology 4 says: :Unstressed variant of ''have'' or ''of''. : Verb :a (third-person singular simple present -, present participle -, simple past and past participle -) :: (archaic or slang) Have. (Now often attached to preceding auxiliary verb.) ::: I shoulda stayed at home last night. I don't think this belongs here. "a" in "shoulda", "coulda", etc. is a reduced pronunciation of "have", a different word from "a"; and even if one accepts that "shoulda" etc. are now verbs, "-a" is a bound morpheme, not a word. I've never seen it written as "should a", with "a" being a separate word. [[User:Duoduoduo|Duoduoduo]] 16:56, 10 October 2011 (UTC) ==RFV== {{archive-top|rfv|failed}} {{fake==|[[a]]}} RFV-senses: "she", "they, them", "it", "I". Like several other senses in other entries, these claim to be senses of a modern English word, yet then restrict themselves via {{temp|defdate}} to a period several centuries before modern English existed. Please either move the senses to ==Middle English== or, preferably, just fix the {{temp|defdate}}s to indicate how long into the modern English period these senses continued and remove the RFV tags. (I hope that at some point our adders of obsolete words will figure out to stop adding words to English sections with defdate ranges that are exclusively pre-1500. It's confusing!) [[User:-sche|- -sche]] [[User talk:-sche|(discuss)]] 17:08, 13 November 2012 (UTC) :RFV-failed for now. [[User:-sche|- -sche]] [[User talk:-sche|(discuss)]] 10:29, 29 December 2012 (UTC) {{archive-bottom}} == Deletion discussion == {{archive-top|rfd|failed}} {{fake==|[[a]]}} Rfd-sense: ''(algebra) The first know quantity, or an unknown quantity in an equation.'' If kept, this should be moved to Translingual. However, I would prefer that it be deleted. In algebra, ''any'' letter can be used as a variable, and they don't have any special meanings beyond being a variable. The only ones that we need are [[x]] and [[y]], I don't see how the others are any helpful. -- [[User:Liliana-60|Liliana]] [[User talk:Liliana-60|•]] 12:18, 13 October 2012 (UTC) *'''Delete'''. --[[User:Wikitiki89|WikiTiki89]] ([[User talk:Wikitiki89|talk]]) 14:00, 13 October 2012 (UTC) * '''Delete''' — ''[[User:Ungoliant MMDCCLXIV|Ungoliant]] ([[User Talk:Ungoliant MMDCCLXIV|Falai]])'' 16:38, 13 October 2012 (UTC) : '''Delete'''. (Why did my RFD on [[n-dimensional]] fail, I wonder?) [[User:Equinox|Equinox]] [[User_talk:Equinox|◑]] 16:44, 13 October 2012 (UTC) :: Because you posted it at WT:RFV instead of at WT:RFD. —[[User: Ruakh |Ruakh]][[User talk: Ruakh |TALK]] 17:08, 13 October 2012 (UTC) ::: ...and because it is frequently found in running text. '''[[User:Spinningspark|Spinning]][[User talk:Spinningspark|Spark]]''' 17:41, 13 October 2012 (UTC) :::: So is "green hat". That doesn't make it non-SoP. [[User:Equinox|Equinox]] [[User_talk:Equinox|◑]] 14:59, 14 October 2012 (UTC) ::@Equinox: feel free to RFD it now... I agree with you that it's SOP. [[User:-sche|- -sche]] [[User talk:-sche|(discuss)]] 19:53, 13 October 2012 (UTC) *'''Keep'''. Why are [[x]] and [[y]] ‘the only ones that we need’? This does have considerable representation in other dictionaries. [[User:Widsith|Ƿidsiþ]] 04:40, 20 October 2012 (UTC) **[[x]] and [[y]] are the only letters with special meaning in algebra (being the first and second variables, respectively). The others are just letters that happen to be used as variables. Unicode has a thousand of them at [[Appendix:Unicode/Mathematical Alphanumeric Symbols]] - are you suggesting we should have an entry for all of them? -- [[User:Liliana-60|Liliana]] [[User talk:Liliana-60|•]] 07:37, 20 October 2012 (UTC) **: Really? What are the "special" meanings of ''[[x]]'' and ''[[y]]'' that don't apply to other variables? --[[User:Wikitiki89|Wiki]][[User talk:Wikitiki89|Tiki]][[Special:Contributions/Wikitiki89|89]] 09:46, 20 October 2012 (UTC) **::x and y are always the first and second variables. You will not find an algebraic formula where x is the fifth variable, or y the third variable, or similar. -- [[User:Liliana-60|Liliana]] [[User talk:Liliana-60|•]] 09:51, 20 October 2012 (UTC) **::::Not true. This is a modern convention, and does not obtain in older mathematical books. [[User:Widsith|Ƿidsiþ]] 10:36, 20 October 2012 (UTC) **::: Challenge accepted! --[[User:Wikitiki89|Wiki]][[User talk:Wikitiki89|Tiki]][[Special:Contributions/Wikitiki89|89]] 10:32, 20 October 2012 (UTC) **:::: [https://www.google.com/search?q=%22n+%3D+x%22&oq=%22n+%3D+x%22&sugexp=chrome,mod=0&sourceid=chrome&ie=UTF-8#q=%22n+%3D+m/x%22&hl=en&prmd=imvns&source=lnms&tbm=bks&sa=X&ei=yoSCUPvyJNH54QS4nYGgCA&ved=0CA0Q_AUoADgU&prmdo=1&bav=on.2,or.r_gc.r_pw.r_qf.&fp=57e5f1262534874b&bpcl=35466521&biw=1920&bih=929 This search result] contains some counterexamples. Don't know if that will satisfy you though. --[[User:Wikitiki89|Wiki]][[User talk:Wikitiki89|Tiki]][[Special:Contributions/Wikitiki89|89]] 11:04, 20 October 2012 (UTC) ***FWIW, [[W:Variable (mathematics)#Naming conventions]] names also the third, ''w'', as a usual unknown, and at [[W:Y]] I found no mention of ''y'''s special usage in mathematics. Anyway, [[unknown#Noun]] meaning in algebra mentions ''z'' as that of the third one. --[[User: Biblbroks|biblbroks]][[User talk: Biblbroks|дискашн]] 09:53, 20 October 2012 (UTC) ****x and y don't have "special meanings", it's just counter intuitive that they should be used as first and second despite their position in the alphabet. But from prime it's usually p and q, (then r, and so on) so x and y are not unique in this way. The fact that algebra doesn't use alphabetical order doesn't justify special definitions of x and y. That would be misrepresentative (possibly untruthful). [[User:Mglovesfun|Mglovesfun]] ([[User talk:Mglovesfun|talk]]) 11:08, 20 October 2012 (UTC) *****Then go ahead and open up a new RFD if you so wish. -- [[User:Liliana-60|Liliana]] [[User talk:Liliana-60|•]] 11:15, 20 October 2012 (UTC) : '''Keep.''' Mathematicians can and do use any letter to mean anything, from various alphabets. I've even seen Σ used as a variable. Talk about confusing! Still, that's not how everyone else uses variables, even those who know math well. : A clear mathematical description would always define or instantiate a variable, and at least name any extraordinary functions like ζ that are introduced. But a lot of times variables are not explained, even in hard sciences like physics and chemistry. If you see ρ you immediately think density, but not if you see d, which means distance. Generally v means velocity, ν means wavelength, and you would be laughed at, even scolded, for switching them. : Even mathematicians will have a preference toward using θ as an angle instead of a, for instance, although capital A as an angle is not uncommon. A lot of the time it also depends on the area of study. In statistics, μ is the mean, σ is the deviation, but both are defined as specific functions in number theory having nothing to do with collections of data. : Of course, if there are two distances, or two means, or two zeroes (!) then other symbols can be used, assuming subscripts are not employed, and explanation for these variables is provided. However, this is an exception. : In this light, lowercase a, b, and c are commonly used in mathematics to define relations between several quantities, not necessarily saying which is unknown. Identities are mainly the examples that come to mind, like the distributive law, square of a sum, and many others. The letters are commonly used for side lengths as in the Pythagorean theorem, which also defines a relation without a specific unknown. : It would be just as correct to say that o2+γ2=Я2, but who's going to label a triangle that way? Even "x squared plus y squared equals z squared" is 20 times less prevalent on Google, and the first few hits indicate a different use, such as the mathematical puzzle of Fermat's last theorem in contrast to a geometric problem, or a trick question for students who think the sides should always be labeled a, b, and c! : In the quadratic equation all three are known, and x instead is the unknown, having a stronger tendency for meaning an unknown. They are likewise constants in other factorizations and in conic sections, defining for instance the x and y intercepts. Of course c is also a constant in physics, and b could represent a quark, though I would guess the latter is fairly uncommon. This gets into the question of verifiability, which is a whole other can of worms. [[User talk:DAVilla|DAVilla]] 11:17, 20 October 2012 (UTC) :: The only thing I fail to grasp is how that's an argument for ''keeping'' it. --[[User:Wikitiki89|Wiki]][[User talk:Wikitiki89|Tiki]][[Special:Contributions/Wikitiki89|89]] 11:23, 20 October 2012 (UTC) :::I agree with Wikitiki89, "Mathematicians can and do use any letter to mean anything, from various alphabets" which you DAVilla write above does seem to be rather a good reason to delete this! The fact that any of a wide range of symbols can be used for any conceivable purposes shows that these aren't definitions. [[User:Mglovesfun|Mglovesfun]] ([[User talk:Mglovesfun|talk]]) 11:29, 20 October 2012 (UTC) :::: Maybe we can have an appendix page documenting various standard uses of variables in physics? --[[User:Wikitiki89|Wiki]][[User talk:Wikitiki89|Tiki]][[Special:Contributions/Wikitiki89|89]] 11:33, 20 October 2012 (UTC) :::::Actually, I think this fails [[WT:CFI]] line one as it's not a word in a language. Though it is attested, I doubt it's idiomatic, as it's not lexical at all. Why would this be more includable than say, a picture of a kitten? [[User:Mglovesfun|Mglovesfun]] ([[User talk:Mglovesfun|talk]]) 17:14, 20 October 2012 (UTC) :::::: Mathematical statements are often interwoven into text because they can be read as text. How the symbols are read depends on the context, e.g. [[=]] can be "equal", "equal to", or "equals"/"is equal to". Examples are easy to find: [http://books.google.com/books?id=hsCQvB1L2-oC&pg=PA173], [http://books.google.com/books?id=BpvLhvMfmagC&pg=PA281], [http://books.google.com/books?id=FCKnqGEP4WEC&pg=PA475]. Here's a (not particularly good) [http://www.erp.sophia.ac.jp/Projects/ese/HowToReadAndGlossary.pdf guide] for Chinese using English. :::::: My argument above says that the variables can have meaning on their own, without introduction, especially in informal contexts. Consider [http://books.google.com/books?id=oyt8iW6B4aUC&pg=PA30 this example] where problem 1.35 starts "The barometer shown in Fig. P1.35 contains mercury (ρ=13.59 g/cm3)." The word "density" does not appear in the problem or anywhere on the page. A mathematician would balk at this use in such a formal context. Although ρ is introduced when the concepts are explained earlier in the chapter, it is essentially defined there as synonymous with density. [[User talk:DAVilla|DAVilla]] 04:59, 25 October 2012 (UTC) ::::::: Yeah but that's clearly under the context of physics and in physics itself variables can have many definitions. Like I said before, it might be a good idea to have an appendix page (such as [[Appendix:Variables in physics]]) listing standard uses of variables in physics, but I don't think they belong in the main namespace. --[[User:Wikitiki89|Wiki]][[User talk:Wikitiki89|Tiki]][[Special:Contributions/Wikitiki89|89]] 09:16, 25 October 2012 (UTC) * '''Delete''' "a" has several meanings in science/maths which it might be worth including in a Translingual section (acceleration and activity are the best known). However, the meaning presented here is useless. Anything can be a variable. "a" on its own in a mathematical equation has no meaning at all. It's just a token which allows the mathematician to keep track of the relationships between variables while manipulating equations. You can use any letter, any symbol, whole words, drawings or even totally invented squiggles for this purpose. [http://www.teacherplus.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/01/classroom-updates.jpg Here's one example]. ''x'' is a little different, in that people actually use it outside equations to mean a missing quantity (see [[sure as eggs is eggs]]). I've never heard of anyone using "a" in that metaphorical sense. [[User:Smurrayinchester|Smurrayinchester]] ([[User talk:Smurrayinchester|talk]]) 13:12, 30 October 2012 (UTC) '''Sense deleted'''. [[User:BD2412|bd2412]] [[User talk:BD2412|'''T''']] 13:09, 12 August 2013 (UTC) {{archive-bottom}} == Deletion discussion 2 == {{archive-top|rfd|failed}} {{fake==|[[a]] 2}} Rfd-sense, there are two issues here: * ''A spoken sound represented by the letter a or A, as in map, mall, or male.'' I can honestly find no usage example for this sense. It would have to be a sentence that actually uses ''a'' to refer to a sound and not just to the letter ''a'' (as in "You spell it like the a in father"). So I believe this is a misguided sense and adequately covered by the letter sense. Then we have these three: * ''A written representation of the letter A or a.'' * ''A printer's type or stamp used to reproduce the letter a.'' * ''An item having the shape of the letter a or A.'' They are really no different from each other, and should be merged into one sense, or just canned altogether and have them be represented by the letter sense. Think of what senses this would allow for [[fish]]: ''An artistic representation of a fish'', ''A printer's type or stamp used to reproduce a fish'' (think Christianity), ''An item having the shape of a fish'', etc. -- [[User:Liliana-60|Liliana]] [[User talk:Liliana-60|•]] 14:26, 17 October 2012 (UTC) :Couldn't we find instances of "the sound as an a"? That should eliminate many spurious hits. (Yes we can: [https://www.google.com/search?tbm=bks&hl=en&q=%22the+sound+of+an+a%22&btnG= bgc]. [[User: DCDuring |DCDuring]] [[User talk: DCDuring|TALK]] 17:06, 17 October 2012 (UTC)) ::But does ''a'' in this instance really refer to "a spoken sound"? If we apply the insertion test (i. e. insert the definition in place of the word) we get something like "the sound of a spoken sound represented by the letter a". Does that make sense to you? -- [[User:Liliana-60|Liliana]] [[User talk:Liliana-60|•]] 17:21, 17 October 2012 (UTC) :::That's easy to read as "the sound (heard) of a spoken sound (produced) etc". Many distinct definitions seem to be be just the results of teasing apart aspects of a phenomenon. [[User: DCDuring |DCDuring]] [[User talk: DCDuring|TALK]] 20:20, 17 October 2012 (UTC) :Of the group of three, it would take a little bit of effort to get all three into a single sense as "representation" implies intent, the second is for a device for producing the letter, and the third is for something that might have the shape by accident. "An item, mark, shape, or image representing or resembling a form of the letter A" includes both 1 and 3 certainly and the letter on Hester Prynne's forehead. Perhaps we would want to include within the third sense a key marked "A" on a keyboard or touchscreen or the part of a typewriter ball or arm used to produce the letter. :As "a"-ness is abstract, it might be useful to have at least one definition that explicitly defines ''a'' as concrete embodiments of the abstract notion. :It would be a service to provide the senses of the letter that are supposed to cover this. I couldn't get [[[[a]]]] to download just now. [[User: DCDuring |DCDuring]] [[User talk: DCDuring|TALK]] 16:27, 17 October 2012 (UTC) :: If your computer system is even slightly slow, [[a]] takes forever to download or will crash your browser. Definitely do NOT try to download the history page. I purchased a brand new $2000 system just to download that page :( {{unsigned|Speednat|07:36, 2 January 2013 (UTC)}} :'''Delete''' per nom. [[User:-sche|- -sche]] [[User talk:-sche|(discuss)]] 03:21, 20 September 2013 (UTC) '''Senses deleted'''. [[User:BD2412|bd2412]] [[User talk:BD2412|'''T''']] 18:20, 22 October 2013 (UTC) {{archive-bottom}} == Deletion discussion 3 == {{archive-top|rfd|failed}} {{fake==|[[a#rfd-sense-notice--|a 3]]}} Rfd-sense: ''Designating a second residence with the same street number.'' I think this sense is misguided. a does not "designate a second residence with the same street number", as in, it doesn't distinguish two buildings which both have the house number 12. Rather, it is itself part of the house number. Letters do appear in house numbers, but they don't carry any inherent meaning and thus aren't dictionary material. -- [[User:Liliana-60|Liliana]] [[User talk:Liliana-60|•]] 19:35, 29 June 2013 (UTC) *'''Delete''' per nom. Fairly clear cut. This is no different than having senses for numbers indicating that they are themselves street addresses. [[User:BD2412|bd2412]] [[User talk:BD2412|'''T''']] 19:38, 29 June 2013 (UTC) *'''Delete''' per bd. [[User:-sche|- -sche]] [[User talk:-sche|(discuss)]] 04:35, 30 June 2013 (UTC) : Well, it is used in deriving a new number from an old one, e.g. a new house is built between 10 and 11 and may be numbered 10a. The French equivalent is ''[[bis]]'', written as a separate word beside the original number. [[User:Equinox|Equinox]] [[User_talk:Equinox|◑]] 05:26, 30 June 2013 (UTC) :: And if there's more than one, wouldn't the second one be 10b? I've also seen fractions: 10 1/2 and 10 3/4. [[User:Chuck Entz|Chuck Entz]] ([[User talk:Chuck Entz|talk]]) 05:55, 30 June 2013 (UTC) : I vote '''keep''', if not obvious from the above. But then I added it :) [[User:Equinox|Equinox]] [[User_talk:Equinox|◑]] 16:32, 26 August 2013 (UTC) : '''Keep'''. It is not clear for me that a new address between 10 and 11 is named 10a rather than 10b. — [[User:TAKASUGI Shinji|TAKASUGI Shinji]] ([[User talk:TAKASUGI Shinji|talk]]) 02:48, 3 September 2013 (UTC) ::So you would support a sense of [[2]] as "designating a second residence on the same street", because it's not obvious that a new address between 1 and 3 is called 2? Appending a isn't even a hard and fast rule, there are exceptions. -- [[User:Liliana-60|Liliana]] [[User talk:Liliana-60|•]] 09:17, 30 November 2013 (UTC) ::: It’s obvious that a new address between 1 and 3 is called 2. — [[User:TAKASUGI Shinji|TAKASUGI Shinji]] ([[User talk:TAKASUGI Shinji|talk]]) 01:33, 27 December 2013 (UTC) : '''Delete'''. This is just a numbering convention, like "Exit 3A" on a highway or "Vitamin B6" (which is the opposite). --[[User:Wikitiki89|Wiki]][[User talk:Wikitiki89|Tiki]][[Special:Contributions/Wikitiki89|89]] 20:37, 27 December 2013 (UTC) :: '''Delete'''. I'm sure you can also find addresses where b is used instead of a on the principle that the original number is implicitly a. It has about as much ''lexical'' significance as the fact that a is used in outlines, along with b, c, d, etc. The fact that letters are used to supplement numbers in numbering schemes is a useful thing to know, as is that fact that such numbers tend to follow numeric and alphabetic order (there's no ''explicit'' requirement that houses not be arranged in the order 3,9,2,7, etc.), but it's not for a dictionary to explain it: I have trouble imagining anyone looking up [[a]] in the dictionary because they saw an address with "3 a" in it. [[User:Chuck Entz|Chuck Entz]] ([[User talk:Chuck Entz|talk]]) 22:33, 27 December 2013 (UTC) '''Deleted'''. — [[User:TAKASUGI Shinji|TAKASUGI Shinji]] ([[User talk:TAKASUGI Shinji|talk]]) 13:02, 13 February 2014 (UTC) {{archive-bottom}} ==Tea Room discussion of Nauruan== For some Tea Room discussion which touched on this entry, see [[Wiktionary:Tea room/2014/June#Nauruan_definition]]. [[User:-sche|- -sche]] [[User talk:-sche|(discuss)]] 15:27, 15 June 2014 (UTC) == [[Wiktionary:Requests for cleanup/archive/2006/Unresolved requests|RFC]] discussion: July 2006–November 2009 == : ''See [[Talk:A#RFC discussion: July 2006–November 2009]].'' == Why is Gothic 𐌳 on see also? == Not that I'm against Gothic being on Wiktionary, but it seems a little weird to have Gothic script be on there and not Cyrillic or Greek. Gothic isn't very common. [[User:Last edited by:|Last edited by:]] ([[User talk:Last edited by:|talk]]) 16:56, 8 January 2017 (UTC) : I moved it to the variations page. — [[User:ObsequiousNewt|ObſequiousNewt]] — [[User talk:ObsequiousNewt|Geſpꝛaͤch]] — [[Special:Contributions/ObsequiousNewt|Beÿtraͤge]] 22:57, 8 January 2017 (UTC) == Lua memory error == {{ping|erutuon}} Suggestions: * adapt the templates showing the whole alphabet to use less memory. * move the translations to subpage WDYT?--[[User:So9q|So9q]] ([[User talk:So9q|talk]]) 12:48, 16 October 2019 (UTC) :Moved the translations which moved the lua errors down from Portuguese to Spanish.--[[User:So9q|So9q]] ([[User talk:So9q|talk]]) 13:21, 16 October 2019 (UTC) :: Reformatted synonyms in the Portuguese section moving it down another bit (from partway through Swahili to partway through Swedish on my computer). [[User:Ilawa-Kataka|İʟᴀᴡᴀ–Kᴀᴛᴀᴋᴀ]] ([[User talk:Ilawa-Kataka|talk]]) ([[Special:Contributions/Ilawa-Kataka|edits]]) 22:16, 16 October 2019 (UTC) == Why is the English section out of the alphabetical order? == Why is English right below the first one? Shouldn’t it follow the alphabetical order and be in its correct spot? {{unsigned-ip|2600:1:C6AD:4949:FC6D:5214:C37C:6442|21:58, 30 April 2020 (UTC)}} : No, Translingual and English go first. See [[Wiktionary:Entry layout#Language]]. — [[User:Erutuon|Eru]]·[[User talk:Erutuon|tuon]] 00:06, 1 May 2020 (UTC) == an one == [https://books.google.es/books?id=BEHFyMCdwssC&lpg=PA66&ots=ysqC8vxFVq&dq=%22An%20was%20an%20acceptable%20alternative%20before%20words%22&hl=es&pg=PA66#v=onepage&q=%22An%20was%20an%20acceptable%20alternative%20before%20words%22&f=false ''An'' was an acceptable alternative before words beginning with a consonant sound but spelled with a vowel (''an one, an united appeal'')] --[[User:Backinstadiums|Backinstadiums]] ([[User talk:Backinstadiums|talk]]) 11:30, 28 June 2020 (UTC) : Might get round to adding this later; it's not because they were spelt with a vowel; it's because they formerly begun with a vowel sound (which is why they're spelt like that). [[User:Hazarasp|Hazarasp]] ([[User talk:Hazarasp|parlement]] · [[Special:Contributions/Hazarasp|werkis]]) 16:00, 28 June 2020 (UTC) : {{done}}; see {{m|en|an}}. [[User:Hazarasp|Hazarasp]] ([[User talk:Hazarasp|parlement]] · [[Special:Contributions/Hazarasp|werkis]]) 17:33, 28 June 2020 (UTC) {{ping|Hazarasp}} In former times '''an''' was used before strongly pronounced '''h''' in a stressed first syllable: '''an hundred'''. https://www.wordreference.com/definition/a --[[User:Backinstadiums|Backinstadiums]] ([[User talk:Backinstadiums|talk]]) 17:52, 4 August 2020 (UTC) == Etymology of [[aes]], plural of the letter a == According to Wikipedia, "Plurals of vowel names add [[-es]] (i.e., aes, ees, ies, oes, ues)". What's the etymology of this [[-es]] ? --[[User:Backinstadiums|Backinstadiums]] ([[User talk:Backinstadiums|talk]]) 23:06, 1 August 2020 (UTC) : I am sceptical of Wikipedia's claim. However there may be a perceived need to avoid confusion with the actual words ''as'', ''is'' and ''us''. I think people usually pluralise letters with an apostrophe: two a's. [[User:Equinox|Equinox]] [[User_talk:Equinox|◑]] 18:31, 4 August 2020 (UTC) ::''Side note: this is the method I would use as a native speaker of American English'': a's", e's, i's, o's, and u's. ''However, I don't know what the "official" or "proper" form is supposed to be.'' I would probably write "y's" too. --[[User:Geographyinitiative|Geographyinitiative]] ([[User talk:Geographyinitiative|talk]]) 00:41, 5 August 2020 (UTC) ::{{reply to|Equinox}} https://www.oed.com/oed2/00000001 --[[User:Backinstadiums|Backinstadiums]] ([[User talk:Backinstadiums|talk]]) 20:45, 4 August 2020 (UTC) ::: {{reply to|Backinstadiums}} That says "the plural of ''a'' has been written ''aes''" (perhaps not very often!): it does not say "there is some kind of general particle or suffix ''-es'' that you can add to any vowel". I think you might be [[overextend]]ing. [[User:Equinox|Equinox]] [[User_talk:Equinox|◑]] 21:59, 4 August 2020 (UTC) :::: ''y'' can be a vowel (''rhythm''): do you think ''yes'' is a vowel plural? [[User:Equinox|Equinox]] [[User_talk:Equinox|◑]] 22:01, 4 August 2020 (UTC) :::::{{reply to|Equinox}} https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/English_alphabet#Modern_letters Why would I lie about it? --[[User:Backinstadiums|Backinstadiums]] ([[User talk:Backinstadiums|talk]]) 23:02, 4 August 2020 (UTC) :::::: As a native English speaker I am convinced you are wrong, and your link doesn't show any proof of ''yes'' as plural of ''y''. Please ask at [[WT:TR]] where other natives can comment. [[User:Equinox|Equinox]] [[User_talk:Equinox|◑]] 00:15, 5 August 2020 (UTC) == [[many a]] == What meaning is used in '''many a(nother)'''? --[[User:Backinstadiums|Backinstadiums]] ([[User talk:Backinstadiums|talk]]) 18:25, 25 September 2020 (UTC) == indefinite article. indefinitely or nonspecifically (used with adjectives expressing number) == indefinite article. indefinitely or nonspecifically (used with adjectives expressing number): ''A great many years; a few stars''. https://www.wordreference.com/definition/a%20few --[[User:Backinstadiums|Backinstadiums]] ([[User talk:Backinstadiums|talk]]) 08:34, 27 September 2020 (UTC) == a /an/ == Before drpping an /h/ the unstressed indefinite article is /an/, or /aʔ/, isn't it? --[[User:Backinstadiums|Backinstadiums]] ([[User talk:Backinstadiums|talk]]) 00:00, 9 November 2020 (UTC) : It's ''an'', as the word becomes vowel-initial. [[User:Hazarasp|Hazarasp]] ([[User talk:Hazarasp|parlement]] · [[Special:Contributions/Hazarasp|werkis]]) 11:34, 14 November 2020 (UTC) == Now often attached to preceding auxiliary verb [[-a]]. == Also to a following word, [[a-]], as in [https://www.google.com/search?tbm=bks&q=%22lawd+a+mercy%22&spell=1&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiBga6y74HtAhVi8uAKHZdqDJQQBQg0KAA&biw=1366&bih=653&dpr=1 ''Lawd hammercy, Lawd a'mercy, Lawd a-mercy''] --[[User:Backinstadiums|Backinstadiums]] ([[User talk:Backinstadiums|talk]]) 10:54, 14 November 2020 (UTC) == before uncountable nouns == [https://www.oxfordlearnersdictionaries.com/definition/english/a_1?q=a Used before uncountable nouns when these have an adjective in front of them, or phrase following them: ''a good knowledge of French; a sadness that won’t go away''] --[[User:Backinstadiums|Backinstadiums]] ([[User talk:Backinstadiums|talk]]) 10:53, 21 November 2020 (UTC) == in front of two nouns that are seen as a single unit == [https://www.oxfordlearnersdictionaries.com/definition/english/a_1?q=a ​used in front of two nouns that are seen as a single unit: '''''a''' knife and fork''] --[[User:Backinstadiums|Backinstadiums]] ([[User talk:Backinstadiums|talk]]) 10:56, 21 November 2020 (UTC) : Why is that a sense of "a"? You can just as well say "the knife and fork" or "my knife and fork". [[User:Equinox|Equinox]] [[User_talk:Equinox|◑]] 13:26, 21 November 2020 (UTC) ::because of plurality of reference, two elements, so it's not a case of elision ''a knife (and a) fork'', unlike ''the'' --[[User:Backinstadiums|Backinstadiums]] ([[User talk:Backinstadiums|talk]]) 16:31, 21 November 2020 (UTC) ::: I don't see how it's different. "A knife and fork ''are'' required; the knife and fork ''are'' required". [[User:Equinox|Equinox]] [[User_talk:Equinox|◑]] 17:17, 21 November 2020 (UTC) When ''and'' is used in common phrases connecting two things or people that are closely linked, the determiner is not '''usually''' repeated before the second: ''a knife and fork, my father and mother'' , but ''a knife and a spoon, my father and my uncle'' . https://www.oxfordlearnersdictionaries.com/definition/english/and?q=and+ --[[User:Backinstadiums|Backinstadiums]] ([[User talk:Backinstadiums|talk]]) 12:03, 23 November 2020 (UTC) == Lua error == It seems there is too many or complex template invocations: much of the page is full of "Lua error: not enough memory". Something ought to be done. –[[User:LPfi|LPfi]] ([[User talk:LPfi|talk]]) 08:51, 8 February 2021 (UTC) : {{reply|LPfi}} See [[Wiktionary:Lua memory errors]]. [[User:J3133|J3133]] ([[User talk:J3133|talk]]) 08:57, 8 February 2021 (UTC) Update July 2021: Too many lua error. :( [[User:P.T.Đ|P.T.Đ]] ([[User talk:P.T.Đ|talk]]) 17:45, 19 July 2021 (UTC) == [[broad a]] == [https://www.wordreference.com/definition/broad The long vowel in English words such as ''father, half'', as represented in the received pronunciation of Southern British English.] --[[User:Backinstadiums|Backinstadiums]] ([[User talk:Backinstadiums|talk]]) 16:06, 18 February 2021 (UTC)

revision.comment: fix; this was changed as part of an uncareful mass replacement recently, but in this case this footnote is a 'quote', saying what notation MW uses
revision.text:
{{shortcut|AP:ENPRON}} ==English== The following tables show the [[International Phonetic Alphabet]] (IPA) and the English pronunciation (enPR) or {{w|American Heritage Dictionary}} (AHD) symbols that are used to represent the various sounds of the {{w|English language}}. The sounds of [[Received Pronunciation]] (RP, UK), [[General American]] pronunciation (GenAm, US), [[Canadian English]] (CanE), [[Australian English]] (AuE){{,}} and [[New Zealand English]] (NZE) are shown.
For vowels in other dialects, see Wikipedia's {{w|IPA chart for English}}. An [[:File:IPA Chart for English 2.png|image of an old version of these tables]] is available.
===[[vowel|Vowels]]=== For a fuller list of dialects, see {{w|International Phonetic Alphabet chart for English dialects}}.
{{w|rhoticity in English|Non-rhotic}} dialects (RP, Australia, New Zealand) do not pronounce what was historically a syllable-final ''r''; instead they have a schwa ({{IPAchar|/ə/}}), centering diphthong (ending in {{IPAchar|/ə̯/}}){{,}} or a long vowel (ending in {{IPAfont|ː}}). Rhotic dialects (General American and Canadian) pronounce the syllable-final ''r''. Also, they make no vowel length distinction, so none of their vowels end in the length symbol {{IPAfont|ː}}.
This vowel table below lists the standard phonemic vowel notations in each accent and contains both [[monophthong]]s and [[diphthong]]s. Variations of notation within the same accent are also listed.
{| class="wikitable" ! colspan="5" | {{w|International Phonetic Alphabet|IPA}} ! rowspan="2" | [[Template:enPR|enPR]] / {{w|American Heritage Dictionary|AHD}} ! rowspan="2" | examples |- ! [[File:Flag of the United Kingdom.svg|30px]] RP !! [[File:Flag of the United States.svg|30px]] GenAm !! [[File:Flag of Canada.svg|30px]] CanE !! [[File:Flag of Australia.svg|30px]] AuE !! [[File:Flag of New Zealand.svg|30px]] NZE |- ! <big>{{IPAfont|ɑː}}</big> !! <big>{{IPAfont|ɑ}}</big> !! <big>{{IPAfont|ɒ, ɑ}}</big> !! colspan="2" | <big>{{IPAfont|ɐː, aː}}</big> ! <big>{{enPRchar|ä}}</big> | {{l|en|father|f'''a'''ther}}, {{l|en|palm|p'''a'''lm}} |- ! <big>{{IPAfont|ɑː}}</big> !! colspan="2" | <big>{{IPAfont|ɑɹ}}</big> !! colspan="2" | <big>{{IPAfont|ɐː, aː}}</big> ! <big>{{enPRchar|är}}</big> | {{l|en|arm|'''ar'''m}}, {{l|en|bard|b'''ar'''d}}, {{l|en|starry|st'''arr'''y}}, {{l|en|start|st'''ar'''t}} |- ! <big>{{IPAfont|æ,}} {{IPAchar2|Open front unrounded vowel.ogg|a}}</big> !! colspan="2" | <big>{{IPAchar2|Near-open front unrounded vowel.ogg|æ}}</big> !! <big>{{IPAfont|æ}}</big> !! <big>{{IPAfont|ɛ}}</big> ! <big>{{enPRchar|ă}}</big> | {{l|en|bad|b'''a'''d}}, {{l|en|cat|c'''a'''t}}, {{l|en|ran|r'''a'''n}}, {{l|en|trap|tr'''a'''p}}<ref name="oxforda">RP {{IPAchar|/æ/}} is sometimes transcribed {{IPAchar|/a/}}, for example in dictionaries of the [[Wikipedia:Oxford University Press|Oxford University Press]].</ref><ref name="badlad">See [[w:bad–lad split|''bad''–''lad'' split]] for more discussion of the vowel {{IPAchar|/æ/}} in Australian English.</ref><!--Will split trap—bath--> |- ! <big>{{IPAfont|æɹ, aɹ}}</big> !! <big>{{IPAfont|æɹ, ɛɹ}}</big> || <big>{{IPAfont|ɛɹ}}</big> !! <big>{{IPAfont|æɹ}}</big> !! <big>{{IPAfont|ɛɹ}}</big> ! <big>{{enPRchar|ăr}}</big> | {{l|en|carry|c'''arr'''y}}, {{l|en|marry|m'''arr'''y}}, {{l|en|paragraph|p'''ar'''agraph}}<ref name="Mary-marry-merry">In many accents in the United States and most accents in Canada, some or all of the vowels of ''Mary'', ''marry''{{,}} and ''merry'' are merged (the [[w:Mary–marry–merry merger|''Mary''–''marry''–''merry'' merger]]). If all three are merged, the resulting vowel is usually transcribed {{IPAchar|/ɛɹ/}}. In accents that distinguish all three, ''marry'' has {{IPAchar|/æɹ/}}, ''merry'' has {{IPAchar|/ɛɹ/}}{{,}} and ''Mary'' has {{IPAchar|/eɹ/}}.</ref> |- ! colspan="3" | <big>{{IPAfont|eɪ}}</big> !! colspan="2" | <big>{{IPAfont|æɪ}}</big> ! <big>{{enPRchar|ā}}</big> | {{l|en|day|d'''ay'''}}, {{l|en|pain|p'''ai'''n}}, {{l|en|hey|h'''ey'''}}, {{l|en|weight|w'''eigh'''t}}, {{l|en|face|f'''a'''ce}} |- ! <big>{{IPAfont|ɛː, ɛə}}</big> !! <big>{{IPAfont|eɹ, ɛɹ}}</big> || <big>{{IPAfont|ɛɹ}}</big> !! <big>{{IPAfont|eː}}</big> !! <big>{{IPAfont|iə, eə}}</big> ! <big>{{enPRchar|âr}}</big> | {{l|en|hair|h'''air'''}}, {{l|en|there|th'''ere'''}}, {{l|en|fairy|f'''air'''y}}, {{l|en|vary|v'''ar'''y}}, {{l|en|Mary|M'''ar'''y}}, {{l|en|square|squ'''are'''}}<ref name="airsymbol">An older alternative symbol to RP {{IPAchar|/ɛː/}} is {{IPAchar|/eə/}}, reflecting the mid height of the vowel in earlier RP, and the fact that it was a centring diphthong.</ref><ref name="RP centring diphthongs">RP in the early 20th century had five centring diphthongs {{IPAchar|/ɑə/|/eə/|/ɪə/|/ɔə/|/ʊə/}}. Of these, {{IPAchar|/ɔə/}} in ''force'' formerly contrasted with a long vowel {{IPAchar|/ɔː/}} in ''north'', ''thought''. All of them are now generally pronounced as long monophthongs (pure vowels) {{IPAchar|/ɑː/|/ɔː/|/ɛː/|/ɪː/|/ɵː/}} ({{w|monophthongization}}). However, many words that formerly had {{IPAchar|/ʊə/}} (= {{IPAchar|/ɵː/}}) are now pronounced with {{IPAchar|/ɔː/}}. {{IPAchar|/ɑə/}} monophthongized first, very early in the 20th century, then {{IPAchar|/ɔə/}}, and more recently the rest.</ref><ref name="near-square">Many speakers of New Zealand English, especially younger speakers, make no distinction between the vowels of ''near'' and ''square''; see [[w:Near–square merger|''near''–''square'' merger]] for more discussion.</ref><ref name="Mary-marry-merry"/> |- ! colspan="3" | <big>{{IPAchar2|Open-mid front unrounded vowel.ogg|ɛ}}</big> !! colspan=2 | <big>{{IPAchar2|Close-mid front unrounded vowel.ogg|e}}</big> ! <big>{{enPRchar|ĕ}}</big> | {{l|en|bed|b'''e'''d}}, {{l|en|egg|'''e'''gg}}, {{l|en|meadow|m'''ea'''dow}}, {{l|en|dress|dr'''e'''ss}}<ref name="collinse">{{IPAchar|/ɛ/}} is sometimes transcribed {{IPAchar|/e/}} for RP—for example, in the Collins English Dictionary.</ref> |- ! colspan="3" | <big>{{IPAfont|ɛɹ}}</big> !! colspan="2" | <big>{{IPAfont|eɹ}}</big> ! <big>{{enPRchar|ĕr}}</big> | {{l|en|very|v'''er'''y}}, {{l|en|error|'''err'''or}}, {{l|en|merry|m'''err'''y}}<ref name="Mary-marry-merry"/> |- ! <big>{{IPAfont|iː}}</big> !! colspan="2" | <big>{{IPAchar2|Close front unrounded vowel.ogg|i}}</big> !! colspan="2" | <big>{{IPAfont|iː}}</big> ! <big>{{enPRchar|ē}}</big> | {{l|en|ease|'''ea'''se}}, {{l|en|see|s'''ee'''}}, {{l|en|siege|s'''ie'''ge}}, {{l|en|ceiling|c'''ei'''ling}}, {{l|en|fleece|fl'''ee'''ce}} |- ! <big>{{IPAfont|ɪə, ɪː}}</big> !! <big>{{IPAfont|ɪɹ}}</big> !! <big>{{IPAfont|iɹ}}</big> !! <big>{{IPAfont|ɪə}}</big> !! <big>{{IPAfont|iə, iːə}}</big> ! <big>{{enPRchar|îr}}</big> | {{l|en|near|n'''ear'''}}, {{l|en|here|h'''ere'''}}, {{l|en|serious|s'''er'''ious}}<ref name="RP centring diphthongs"/><ref name="near-square"/> |- ! <big>{{IPAfont|ɪ, i, iː}}</big> !! colspan="2" | <big>{{IPAfont|i}}</big> !! colspan="2" | <big>{{IPAfont|iː}}</big> ! (<big>{{enPRchar|ē}}</big>) | {{l|en|city|cit'''y'''}}, {{l|en|happy|happ'''y'''}}, {{l|en|everyday|ever'''y'''day}}, {{l|en|mania|man'''i'''a}}, {{l|en|geography|g'''e'''ography}}<ref name="happYvowel">In some dictionaries such as the Longman and the Collins English dictionaries, {{IPAchar|/i/}} is used as an [[archiphoneme]] to represent the neutralization of the distinction between {{IPAchar|/ɪ/}} and {{IPAchar|/iː/}} in this position.</ref> |- ! colspan="4" | <big>{{IPAchar2|Near-close near-front unrounded vowel.ogg|ɪ}}</big> !! | <big>{{IPAchar2|schwa.ogg|ə}}</big> ! <big>{{enPRchar|ĭ}}</big> | {{l|en|sit|s'''i'''t}}, {{l|en|city|c'''i'''ty}}, {{l|en|bit|b'''i'''t}}, {{l|en|will|w'''i'''ll}}, {{l|en|kit|k'''i'''t}} |- ! <big>{{IPAchar2|Near-close central unrounded vowel.ogg|ɪ}}</big> !! colspan="4" | <big>{{IPAfont|ə}}</big> ! See e.g. ''[https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/borrow borrow]'', ''[https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/sorry sorry]'', ''[https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/horror horror]'', ''[https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/forest forest]'' in Merriam-Webster.</ref><ref name="prevocalic or">This sequence only occurs before another vowel. Compare the note about the ''nurse'' vowel, /ɜɹ ~ əɹ/.<!--This has been discussed at [[Wiktionary:Beer parlour/2022/November#ʌ in American English pronunciations]].--></ref> |- ! <big>{{IPAfont|ɜː}}</big> !! colspan="2" | <big>{{IPAfont|ɜɹ}}</big> !! <big>{{IPAchar2|Open-mid central unrounded vowel.ogg|ɜː}}</big> !! <big>{{IPAchar2|Close-mid front rounded vowel.ogg|øː}}</big> ! <big>{{enPRchar|ûr}}</big> | {{l|en|fur|f'''ur'''}}, {{l|en|blurry|bl'''urr'''y}}, {{l|en|bird|b'''ir'''d}}, {{l|en|swerve|sw'''er'''ve}}, {{l|en|nurse|n'''ur'''se}}<ref>For RP, {{IPAchar|/əː/}} is sometimes used as an alternative to {{IPAchar|/ɜː/}}—for example, in dictionaries of the {{w|Oxford University Press}}.</ref><ref name="North American er">Similarly, some linguists, such as [https://wstyler.ucsd.edu/posts/difference_schwa_wedge.html Will Styler, professor of linguistics at UC San Diego], argue that /ɜɹ/ is not phonemically distinct from /əɹ/ in General American and Canadian English. The two are traditionally transcribed this way for consistency with the Received Pronunciation transcription system and because they differ in aspects like stress. This has been discussed at [[Wiktionary:Beer parlour/2022/November#/ɝ/ vs /ɚ/ in GenAm]].</ref> |- ! colspan="5" | <big>{{IPAchar2|Schwa.ogg|ə}}</big> ! <big>{{enPRchar|ə}}</big> | {{l|en|Rosa|Ros'''a'''<nowiki>'</nowiki>s}}, {{l|en|about|'''a'''bout}}, {{l|en|oppose|'''o'''ppose}}, {{l|en|comma|comm'''a'''}} |- ! <big>{{IPAfont|ə}}</big> !! colspan="2" | <big>{{IPAchar2|En-us-er.ogg|əɹ}}</big> !! <big>{{IPAfont|ə}}</big> !! <big>{{IPAfont|ə, ɐ, a}}</big> ! <big>{{enPRchar|ər}}</big> | {{l|en|winner|winn'''er'''}}, {{l|en|enter|ent'''er'''}}, {{l|en|error|err'''or'''}}, {{l|en|doctor|doct'''or'''}}, {{l|en|letter|lett'''er'''}}<ref name="North American er"/> |}
<references/>
In order to allow [[Module:syllables]] to count syllables, the disyllabic sequence {{IPAchar|/iə/}} must be transcribed with a period to mark the syllable break – {{IPAchar|/i.ə/}} – so that it will not be confused with the New Zealand diphthong {{IPAchar|/iə/}}.
Syllable-final {{IPAchar|/ɹ/}} is sometimes replaced with {{IPAchar|/ɚ/}}: {{IPAchar|/ðɛɚ/}} instead of {{IPAchar|/ðɛɹ/}}. In order to keep [[Module:syllables]] from counting {{IPAchar|/ɚ/}} as a syllable, add the non-syllabic diacritic: {{IPAchar|/ðɛɚ̯/}}.
Some speakers [[:w:Phonological history of English close front vowels#Weak vowel merger|do not contrast unstressed /ɪ/ and /ə/]], or the two sounds may be in free variation. Some sources use the symbol ⟨[[ɨ]]⟩ or ⟨[[ᵻ]]⟩ to indicate the vowel which results from the merger of, or which may be pronounced as either of, these sounds.<ref>C. Upton; Kretzschmar; Konopka; ''Oxford Dictionary of Pronunciation for Current English'', (2001, Oxford University Press)</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Key to Pronunciation|title=Oxford English Dictionary|url=http://www.oed.com/public/keytopronunciation|publisher=Oxford University Press}}</ref>

<references/>
====Fortis and lenis==== The so-called voiceless and voiced obstruents are more properly {{w|fortis and lenis}}. Each member of a fortis–lenis pair is distinguished from the other by various articulatory and auditory features, but not consistently by voicing or lack of it.
In most dialects of English, the fortis (voiceless) stops and affricate {{IPAchar|/p t tʃ k/}} are always voiceless, and are aspirated ({{IPAchar|[pʰ tʰ tʃʰ kʰ]}}) at the beginning of a word and at the beginning of a stressed syllable: for example, RP ''today'' {{IPAchar|[tʰəˈdeɪ]}}, ''chain'' {{IPAchar|[tʃʰeɪn]}} and ''account'' {{IPAchar|[əˈkʰaʊnt]}}. Vowels and [[w:sonorant|sonorant]]s immediately preceding syllable final fortis obstruents are usually pronounced shorter than before lenis obstruents, as in [[bet|''b'''e'''t'']] vs. [[bed|''b'''e'''d'']] and [[bent|''be'''n'''t'']] vs. [[bend|''be'''n'''d'']]. This phenomenon is known as pre-fortis [[w:Clipping (phonetics)|clipping]].
The lenis (voiced) stops and affricate {{IPAchar|/b d dʒ ɡ/}} are always unaspirated. Lenis obstruents {{IPAchar|/b v ð d z dʒ ʒ ɡ/}} are often devoiced at the beginning or end of words, but are fully voiced between voiced vowels and sonorants.
The fortis–lenis distinction is neutralized in a few cases.
Initial consonant clusters consisting of {{IPAchar|/s/}} and a stop (as in {{m|en|spill}}, {{m|en|still}}, {{m|en|skill}}) are typically analyzed as having a fortis stop, which agrees with the spelling, but may be analyzed equally well as having a lenis stop (i.e., {{m|en||*sbill}}, {{m|en||*sdill}}, {{m|en||*sgill}}). The stop is both voiceless and unaspirated, and there is no additional phonetic feature that establishes it as either fortis or lenis.
In addition, some dialects have a sound change known as intervocalic alveolar {{w|flapping}}, in which {{IPAchar|/t d/}} are both pronounced as an alveolar flap {{IPAchar|[ɾ]}} between vowels or liquids and when not at the beginning of a stressed syllable. Further, in American English, {{IPAchar|/nt/}} between vowels may be pronounced as a nasalized alveolar flap, {{IPAchar|[ɾ̃]}}. The fortis stop {{IPAchar|/t/}} loses its distinctive voicelessness, and essentially becomes lenis. Flapping causes {{m|en|latter}} and {{m|en|ladder}} to both be pronounced as {{IPAchar|[ˈɫæɾɚ]}}, and causes {{m|en|winter}} to be pronounced as {{IPAchar|[ˈwɪɾ̃ɚ]}}, similar to {{m|en|winner}} {{IPAchar|[ˈwɪ̃nɚ]}}.
===Other symbols=== A stress mark is placed before the syllable that is stressed in IPA and after it in enPR / AHD.
{| class="wikitable" ! {{w|International Phonetic Alphabet|IPA}} ! enPR<br>({{w|American Heritage Dictionary|AHD}}) ! indicates |- | {{IPAfont|ˈ}} ({{IPAfont|ˈa}}) | {{enPRchar|ʹ}} ({{enPRchar|aʹ}}) | primary {{w|Stress (linguistics)|stress}}, as in ''rapping'' {{IPAchar|/ˈɹæpɪŋ/}} |- | {{IPAfont|ˌ}} ({{IPAfont|ˌa}}) | {{enPRchar|'}} ({{enPRchar|a'}}) | {{w|secondary stress}} when before the primary stress;<br>unstressed full vowel when after the primary stress, as in ''battlefield'' (phonetically {{IPAchar|[ˈbætəlˌfiːld]}}, phonologically {{IPAchar|/ˈbætəlfiːld/}}) |- | {{IPAfont|a.a}} | {{enPRchar|a-a}} | division between [[syllable]]s |- |  ̩ | | syllabic consonant, as in ''ridden'' {{IPAchar|[ˈɹɪdn̩]}} |- | {{IPAfont|ʔ}} | | {{w|glottal stop}}, as in ''uh-oh'' {{IPAchar|/ˈʌʔoʊ/|[ˈʌ̆ʔ˦oʊ˨]}} |- | {{IPAfont| ̃}} ({{IPAfont|ã}}) | {{enPRchar|ɴ}} ({{enPRchar|aɴ}}) | {{w|nasalization}}, as in ''croissant'' {{IPAchar|/ˈkɹwæsɒ̃/}} |}
'''Note:''' The EnPR and print AHD marks are formatted slightly differently. Online, AHD writes both {{enPRchar|'}}, though they do not always represent the same phoneme.<!--When in the order secondary-primary, they represent the same phoneme. However, when primary-secondary, they do not, and dictionaries such as the OED simply omit the secondary.-->
==See also== * [[Appendix:Pronunciation list of English words]] * Wikipedia's article on {{w|English phonology}} * Wikipedia's {{w|International Phonetic Alphabet chart for English dialects|IPA chart for English dialects}} (and for conversion to ASCII, the {{w|SAMPA chart for English}}) * Wikipedia's article on {{w|Pronunciation respelling for English}} * {{w|Help:IPA for English}} on Wikipedia
==References== * {{cite-book| last=Gimson| first=A. C.| authorlink=Alfred C. Gimson| title=An Introduction to the Pronunciation of English| edition=3rd edn.| publisher=Edward Arnold| year=1980| location=London|isbn=0-7131-6287-2}} * {{cite-book| last=Kenyon| first=John Samuel| authorlink=John Samuel Kenyon| title=American Pronunciation| publisher=George Wahr| location=Ann Arbor| year=1950| edition=10th edn.}} * {{cite-book| last=Kenyon| first=John S.| coauthors=Thomas A. Knott| title=A Pronouncing Dictionary of American English| publisher=Merriam-Webster| location=Springfield, Mass.| year=1944/1953|isbn=0-87779-047-7}} * {{cite-book| last=Wells| first=J. C.| authorlink=John C. Wells| title=Longman Pronunciation Dictionary| publisher=Pearson Education Limited| location=Harlow, Essex| edition=2nd edn.| year=2000|isbn=0-582-36468-X}}
==External links== *[http://www.antimoon.com/how/pronunc-soundsipa.htm Learning the IPA for English], (Standard American English) *[http://hctv.humnet.ucla.edu/departments/linguistics/VowelsandConsonants/course/chapter1/chapter1.html IPA chart] with [[AIFF]] sound files for IPA symbols *[https://web.uvic.ca/ling/resources/ipa/charts/IPAlab/IPAlab.htm IPA chart] with [[MP3]] sound files for all IPA symbols on the chart (limited version is available to anyone) *[http://www.langsci.ucl.ac.uk/ipa/IPA_chart_%28C%292005.pdf The International Phonetic Alphabet (revised to 2005)] Symbols for all languages are shown on this one-page chart. *[http://people.pwf.cam.ac.uk/ssb22/gradint/lexconvert.html lexconvert] a GPL command-line program to convert between Unicode IPA and the ASCII notations of various English speech synthesizers

v. i. is verb intranstive, v. t. is verb transitive. -- [[User:Zoe|Zoe]]
== Proto-Germanic ==
I'm assuming this is cognate to Latin {{m|la|corvus}} ({{IPAchar|/kor.wus/}}) so there's a Proto-Indo-European root somewhere. [[User:Mglovesfun|Mglovesfun]] ([[User talk:Mglovesfun|talk]]) 22:56, 3 July 2010 (UTC) :No, that's not possible – you forgot to consider the Germanic consonant shift (Grimm's law). Only *''hrabnaz'' "raven" can be connected with ''corvus'' (but only via a root etymology; presumably a root *''ker-'' "to shout", though it does not seem to be attested as a verb: I haven't found a fitting root in LIV). The root you are looking for is {{m|ine-pro|*gerh₂-}} "to cry hoarsely" (though this is another noise root à la Pokorny that seems to be found only in nominal derivations: again, nothing in LIV). --[[User:Florian Blaschke|Florian Blaschke]] ([[User talk:Florian Blaschke|talk]]) 22:16, 3 July 2013 (UTC)

Any reason why the Northern English slang definition of crow as snot/booger/bogey isn't included here?
