Striking.​—[[User:Msh210|msh210]]℠ ([[user talk:Msh210|talk]]) 19:08, 19 August 2010 (UTC) {{archive-bottom}} ==RFV discussion 2== {{archive-top|rfv|archived}} Can someone explain to me why [[Wiktionary]] failed RFV per inclusion of brands? The [[Citations:Wiktionary]] are the following ones: * Q1: '''2008''', John Broughton, ''Wikipedia: the missing manual'', O'Reilly Media, page 428 *:The sister projects that the Wikimedia foundation supports, such as '''Wiktionary''', fulfill some of the roles that Wikipedia does not. * Q2: '''2009''', Isabel González-Pueyo, ''Teaching Academic and Professional English Online'', Peter Lang, page 169 *:Besides the renowned '''Wiktionary''' (http://www.wiktionary.org/), a multilingual, Web-based project to create a free content dictionary, available in over 150 languages and run by the Wikimedia foundation... * Q3: '''2009''', Thanaruk Theeramunkong, Boonserm Kijsirikul, Nick Cercone, Tu Bao Ho, ''Advances in Knowledge Discovery and Data Mining: 13th Pacific-Asia Conference, PAKDD 2009 Bangkok, Thailand, April 27-30, 2009 Proceedings'', Springer, page 275 *:In this regard, we are planning to incorporate dynamic linguistic resources such as '''Wiktionary''' to complement the encyclopaedic nature of Wikipedia. The requirements on the brand to be included are the following[http://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Wiktionary:Votes/pl-2007-07/Brand_names_of_products]: * R1. It is used in at least three durably archived independent citations by different authors spanning a period of at least three years; * R2. The citations do not identify the type of product to which the brand name applies, either by stating the class of product, or by stating some feature of the product known to be unique to the class of product; * R3. The citations are not written by or about the manufacturer of the product, nor are they by or about a person, group, or agency associated with the manufacture or sale of the type of product; * R4. The citations are not from a source which is about the type of product in general. Which of the requirements R2-R4 do the provided citations of "Wiktionary" fail? Do all the citations fail the requirements or do some of the citations meet the requirements R2-R4? If some of the citations meet the requirements, I would add more citations so that "Wiktionary" can be included. I do not claim to fully understand the requirements. --[[User:Dan Polansky|Dan Polansky]] 09:03, 11 October 2010 (UTC) :Uh, [[Wiktionary:Votes/pl-2007-07/Brand names of products]] is not the policy. That vote failed, and was restructured as [[Wiktionary:Votes/2007-08/Brand names of products 2]], which passed. --[[User:Yair rand|Yair rand]] ([[User talk:Yair rand|talk]]) 09:47, 11 October 2010 (UTC) :: Oh, I am sorry; I should have looked at [[Wiktionary:Votes/pl-2007-08/Brand names of products 2]]. Which of the requirements stated in that vote do the citations above or their sources fail? Do all the citations fail the requirements? --[[User:Dan Polansky|Dan Polansky]] 11:10, 11 October 2010 (UTC) ::: Well, if we take Wiktionary to be "a brand name for a physical product" (such that [[Wiktionary:Criteria for inclusion#Brand names]] applies), then the Wikimedia Foundation must fall somewhere in the set of "the manufacturer, distributors, retailers, marketers, and advertisers, their parent companies, subsidiaries, and affiliates", such that the 2008 and first 2009 citations are invalid. And the second 2009 quotation seems to be "stating explicitly or implicitly some feature or use of the product from which its type and purpose may be surmised, or some inherent quality that is necessary for an understanding of the author’s intent". So if — ''if'' — we apply the brand-name-for-a-physical-product requirements, then I don't think any of those quotations is valid. (If we don't apply those requirements, then I have no idea which rules ''do'' apply. [[Wiktionary:Criteria for inclusion#Names of specific entities]]?) —[[User: Ruakh |Ruakh]][[User talk: Ruakh |TALK]] 11:16, 11 October 2010 (UTC) :::: Do you say that the citations fail to meet the following requirement: "The source of the citation must be independent of any parties with economic interest in the product, including the manufacturer, distributors, retailers, marketers, and advertisers, their parent companies, subsidiaries, and affiliates, at time of authorship"? Or any other requirement? :::: I have broken down for me the requirements as follows: :::: There must be three independent citations spanning a period of at least three years, from durably archived sources, such that each of the following requirements holds of each citation. ::::* R1: The source of the citation must be independent of any parties with economic interest in the product, including the manufacturer, distributors, retailers, marketers, and advertisers, their parent companies, subsidiaries, and affiliates, at time of authorship. ::::* R2: The source of the citation must not identify any such parties mentioned in the previous point. ::::* R3: The source of the citation must not indicate any legal protection of the brand name as a trademark. ::::* R4: The source of the citation must not be written by any person or group associated with the type of product. ::::* R5: The source of the citation must not be written about any person or group specifically associated with the product. ::::* R6: The source of the citation must not be written about the type of product in general. ::::* R7: The text preceding and surrounding the citation must not identify the product to which the brand name applies, whether by stating explicitly or implicitly some feature or use of the product from which its type and purpose may be surmised[inferred?], or some inherent quality that is necessary for an understanding of the author’s intent. :::: The second citation seems to fail R7; I can find citations that hopefully meet R7 if this is the major problem. --[[User:Dan Polansky|Dan Polansky]] 11:34, 11 October 2010 (UTC) :::: "Wiktionary" is not a brand of a ''physical'' product, but I have assumed that the "physical" differentia is mainly irrelevant anyway; "Windows" by Microsoft would also come under that regulation regardless of whether it is a physical product. Formally, CFI would have to be amended, and "physical" would have to be removed, but I take WT:BRAND to apply to "Wiktionary", for the sake of this argument anyway. --[[User:Dan Polansky|Dan Polansky]] 11:40, 11 October 2010 (UTC) :::: The first citation seems to fail R2. --[[User:Dan Polansky|Dan Polansky]] 11:44, 11 October 2010 (UTC) :::: What about Q4: 'The term vibe is also defined in the Wiktionary as "The atmosphere or aura of a person ..."'[http://books.google.com/books?id=KeBOKTTRMsUC&lpg=PA212&dq=%22Wiktionary%22&pg=PA212#v=onepage&q=%22Wiktionary%22&f=false]. Which requirement does it fail? Does "defined in the X" imply that X is a dictionary, leading to the failure of R7? --[[User:Dan Polansky|Dan Polansky]] 11:49, 11 October 2010 (UTC) :::::Yes, precisely. See [[[[Wiktionary:Criteria for inclusion/Brand names]]]].​—[[User:Msh210|msh210]]℠ ([[user talk:Msh210|talk]]) 20:00, 11 October 2010 (UTC) :::::: So you say that Q4 fails R7. From what specific text of [[Wiktionary:Criteria for inclusion/Brand names]] does it follow? If a word is defined in X, how do you know that X is a dictionary rather than a book on a specific subject that also contains definitions, as many scholarly texts do? I am not convinced. Of course, the very name "Wiktionary" is suggestive of its being a dictionary, but that should not really count toward anything. And on the wording of R7: "The text preceding and surrounding the citation must not identify the product to which the brand name applies": what does it mean to identify a product? The product is the particular work, right? Does the author of the sentence mean "product type" ("dictionary") rather than "product" ("Wiktionary")? ::::::: See my response below. [[User talk:DAVilla|DAVilla]] 14:29, 14 October 2010 (UTC) :::::: What do you say about Q3, given above? :::::: What do you say about Q6, given below? --[[User:Dan Polansky|Dan Polansky]] 07:14, 12 October 2010 (UTC) :::: What about Q5, as vulnerable to R7 as Q4: "Wiktionary defines luck as, "Something that happens to someone by chance, a chance occurrence."[http://books.google.com/books?id=YC49DXW-_60C&lpg=PA329&dq=%22Wiktionary%22&pg=PA329#v=onepage&q=%22Wiktionary%22&f=false] :::: More quotes of the sort of Q4 and Q5 can be found in Google books. :::: What about Q6: "If you were to build a viewer based on Wikipedia or Wiktionary and prevent users from interacting with WV, they would only be able to view the entry that came up based on the word they typed into a filed you provide for them on the layout."[http://books.google.com/books?id=GREMFxeyypAC&lpg=PA455&dq=%22Wiktionary%22&pg=PA455#v=onepage&q=%22Wiktionary%22&f=false] :::: {{unsigned|Dan Polansky|12:11, 11 October 2010 (UTC)}} ::: Some of the criteria mentioned are very sound, especially R1, but, if this word fails RfV, then rules have to be improved. Another rule states that we accept all words, everybody seems to forget this other rule. From what I can see, they could be vulnerable to R7, but I really wonder how the case that they fail R7 would be specifically argued. --[[User:Dan Polansky|Dan Polansky]] 11:06, 13 October 2010 (UTC) ::::Q6 passes, I think. [http://en.wiktionary.org/w/index.php?title=Citations:Wiktionary&action=historysubmit&diff=10664505&oldid=10664497 This] cite might work, as it's not completely clear that it's referencing a dictionary, but the one above it probably doesn't pass R7. Q3 probably doesn't pass R1. --[[User:Yair rand|Yair rand]] ([[User talk:Yair rand|talk]]) 21:25, 13 October 2010 (UTC) ::::: How does does Q3 fail R1? The authors of the Q3 scholarly article are from School of Computer Science and Software Engineering, University of Western Australia[http://books.google.com/books?id=4ChLGEACPosC&lpg=PA275&ots=_Xa-_DhwbG&pg=PA266#v=onepage&q&f=false]. What has this to do with "R1: The source of the citation must be independent of any parties with economic interest in the product, including the manufacturer, distributors, retailers, marketers, and advertisers, their parent companies, subsidiaries, and affiliates, at time of authorship"? --[[User:Dan Polansky|Dan Polansky]] 06:58, 18 October 2010 (UTC) [unindent] I'm sure the wording could use some refinement, and although it was that wording that passed the vote, it may be useful for me to clarify the intent. By "identifying the product" one would be giving as much information about the product as is necessary to understand the quotation. So if Wiktionary were noted as a dictionary then the citation would almost certainly not count. (A counterexample might be something that refers to the wiki rather than dictionary aspect of Wiktionary without further explanation. "ABigCat.com is to Rosetta as '''Wiktionary''' is to Webster." I couldn't imagine any author using this in analogy, so the example is mostly theoretical. The Jonathan Stars quotation is good as it seems to not indicate either.) In my view, even though some of the newer quotations do not state the product type, they identify Wiktionary as a place where things are defined, which (unless I missed something) is all that's really necessary to understand the meaning. [[User talk:DAVilla|DAVilla]] 14:29, 14 October 2010 (UTC) : Let me ask specifically: which of the four quotations Q3-Q6 do pass the requirements, according to your reading of the requirements? (Q1 and Q2 are out, as they mention Wikimedia.) --[[User:Dan Polansky|Dan Polansky]] 07:02, 18 October 2010 (UTC) :: Q3 identifies Wiktionary as a "dynamic linguistic resource". Q5&6 identify Wiktionary as a place where words are defined. "An understanding of the author’s intent" could be gained without the example, by saying passively (with no subject) words are defined as such and such. In my view, only Q4 has any claim. It does not occur in a parenthetical or nonessential phrase, being used in fact to explain another idea. No appositive substitutes as a synonym, nor more generally does Jonathan Stars explain the term anywhere in the work. It's not a great citation since you really only have to understand that these webpages are interactive to get his point, plus you could guess at what Wiktionary is knowing the meaning of ''Wikipedia'' (the rules are not clear here), but arguably ''interactive webpage'' doesn't technically "identify the product" with any information that would indicate "its type and purpose". I strongly suggest the community to check all English entries for [r], the trilled "r", which is neither RP nor GA. [ɹ] should be used instead. A counterargument I often hear are that there is no confusion and that [ɾ], [ɹ] and [r] are allophonic. However, using the latter definitely shows a foreign accent. Another counterargument is that it's easier to type [r] than [ɹ], but laziness is not an excuse at all. Finally people might say that [ɹ] is too confusing for people and that we should keep it simple. That is not the intention of IPA. IPA should help people to pronounce words correctly whatever their native language is. If someone is confused, then they should probably first learn what IPA is and what the symbols mean.You may argue that [r] is just a broad transcription. No, it's not. It's an entirely different sound produced very differently than [ɹ] although they are both written as "r". It's not that we forgot to add diacritics, the two sounds have nothing else in common. If we keep writing [r] instead of [ɹ], that means if every language decides on it its own which symbol corresponds to which sound, IPA loses its meaning. It would be just an alphabet, not a phonetic transcription. --[[Special:Contributions/2.245.192.127|2.245.192.127]] 14:44, 24 August 2014 (UTC) == [[Wiktionary:Requests for deletion/English|RFD]] discussion: August 2019–February 2020 == {{archive-top|rfd|passed|link=Special:PermanentLink/58744709#Wiktionary}} {{fake==|1= [[:Wiktionary#rfd-notice--|Wiktionary]] }} Smartly, we deleted [[Wikibooks]]. This has failed RFD a couple of times, but without any decent reasons. --[[User:Gibraltar Rocks|Gibraltar Rocks]] ([[User talk:Gibraltar Rocks|talk]]) 00:11, 20 August 2019 (UTC) :Before we start this, please remember that the argument "we are Wiktionary so we should have an entry for ourselves" sucks. --[[User:Gibraltar Rocks|Gibraltar Rocks]] ([[User talk:Gibraltar Rocks|talk]]) 00:14, 20 August 2019 (UTC) : It was deleted in 2009 having failed RFV, this should be an RFV not an RFD. I wouldn't be shocked if Wikibooks would be citable now. - [[User:TheDaveRoss|TheDaveRoss]] 02:59, 20 August 2019 (UTC) :: Disconfirmed by the log[https://en.wiktionary.org/w/index.php?title=Special:Log&page=Wiktionary]. --[[User:Dan Polansky|Dan Polansky]] ([[User talk:Dan Polansky|talk]]) 08:06, 23 August 2019 (UTC) ::: Those are the logs for {{m|en|Wiktionary}}, I was talking about {{m|en|Wikibooks}}. You can feel free to confirm it with the logs if you want. - [[User:TheDaveRoss|TheDaveRoss]] 11:58, 17 September 2019 (UTC) : '''Sigh, really, move to RFV'''. [[User:Equinox|Equinox]] [[User_talk:Equinox|◑]] 03:07, 20 August 2019 (UTC) :: No point moving this to RFV; there are already seven citations on the entry page added by me so it clearly passes RFV (note that this entry was WOTD on 12 December 2017). If any decision is to be made about the status of the entry, it should be made here. — [[User:Sgconlaw|SGconlaw]] ([[User talk:Sgconlaw|talk]]) 07:28, 20 August 2019 (UTC) : Wiktionary did not fail any RFD discussion, as per [[Talk:Wiktionary]]; the only RFD discussion there is [[Talk:Wiktionary#RFD discussion]] and it seems to have been not a RFD proper but rather a request to help resolve the inbound links. [[Talk:Wiktionary]] contains two archived RFV discussions; [[Talk:Wiktionary#RFV discussion 2]] discusses whether the provided quotations meet [[WT:BRAND]]. Logs for [[Wiktionary]] entry[https://en.wiktionary.org/w/index.php?title=Special:Log&page=Wiktionary] show the entry was deleted on 18 August 2010 as "Failed RFV" but then it was restored on the same day: "restore until Special:WhatLinksHere/Wiktionary has been addressed". The question probably still remains whether [[Citations:Wiktionary]] has citations meeting [[WT:BRAND]]. The following citation is example of what I think meets [[WT:BRAND]]: 'The Wiktionary says that an atheist is "A person who does not believe that deities exist; one who lacks belief in gods"'; definitions are found not only in dictionaries. --[[User:Dan Polansky|Dan Polansky]] ([[User talk:Dan Polansky|talk]]) 08:06, 23 August 2019 (UTC) ::I would say that "The Wiktionary" is quite possibly just a mistake for "Wiktionary" -- someone not knowing how to correctly refer to it. (What they quote is our old definition e.g. at [https://en.wiktionary.org/w/index.php?title=atheist&oldid=6562605].) You see it as something more than this? [[User:Mihia|Mihia]] ([[User talk:Mihia|talk]]) 16:51, 30 August 2019 (UTC) ::: My only concern is whether the quotation supports [[WT:BRAND]]; it seems to me that it does, and if you think it doesn't, let's hear what part of [[WT:BRAND]] it fails and why. --[[User:Dan Polansky|Dan Polansky]] ([[User talk:Dan Polansky|talk]]) 17:06, 30 August 2019 (UTC) :::: I don't claim to understand [[WT:BRAND]]. However, I just assumed that referring to a brand name in its normal meaning would not qualify. For example, a citation "Collins Dictionary says that an atheist is ..." would not be grounds for our including an entry for "Collins Dictionary", would it? Your quote is likely just the same as this, except miswritten. [[User:Mihia|Mihia]] ([[User talk:Mihia|talk]]) 17:12, 30 August 2019 (UTC) ::::: The particular wording of [[WT:BRAND]] has to be used to exclude a quotation. A quotation using the term "Collins Dictionary" fails "must not identify the product or service to which the brand name applies"; this does not apply to "Wiktionary" unless one considers the term "Wiktionary" to automatically fail by its *tionary shape. --[[User:Dan Polansky|Dan Polansky]] ([[User talk:Dan Polansky|talk]]) 17:23, 30 August 2019 (UTC) :::::: I don't understand what you mean, unless it is a silly quibble about "Collins Dictionary" including the word "Dictionary". Just substitute anything else. Does a citation 'Wiktionary says that an atheist is "A person who does not believe that deities exist; one who lacks belief in gods"' support inclusion of "Wiktionary" or not? If it does, then you could substitute any normal reference to any brand name. [[User:Mihia|Mihia]] ([[User talk:Mihia|talk]]) 17:38, 30 August 2019 (UTC) ::::::: What I mean is indeed in reference to "Collins Dictionary" containing the word "dictionary" and that is in reference to "The text preceding and surrounding the citation must not identify the product or service to which the brand name applies, whether by stating explicitly or implicitly some feature or use of the product or service from which its type and purpose may be surmised, or some inherent quality that is necessary for an understanding of the author’s intent." But maybe I am applying it wrongly and I should look at text ''preceding'' and ''surrounding'' the quotation rather than at the quotation itself. In fact, reading the policy as written, it would be okay if the quotation itself identified the product or service; it is just the text ''around'' it that must not do so. I find the quoted passage of [[WT:BRAND]] really unfortunate and worthy of removal. In any case, what matters is the wording of [[WT:BRAND]], not vague hunches that make no reference to the wording. As for your question, you can see that whether a quotation supports [[WT:BRAND]] depends not only on the quotation itself but also on the text around the quotation. Link to the text around is at [[Citations:Wiktionary]]. Using the wording of [[WT:BRAND]], it seems to me that the quotation and the text around it support inclusion of [[Wiktionary]]. --[[User:Dan Polansky|Dan Polansky]] ([[User talk:Dan Polansky|talk]]) 18:40, 30 August 2019 (UTC) :::::::: I think technically you may be applying it wrongly since "Dictionary" is actually a part of the brand name, but all this is missing the main point that I am trying to make, which is how is 'Wiktionary says that an atheist is ...' different from any possible citation that you could find that refers to any brand name in its ordinary capacity, and if such a citation qualifies "Wiktionary" for inclusion then we could find an essentially analogous citation to support inclusion of any brand name whatsoever, which surely cannot be the intention of [[WT:BRAND]]. This is what I do not understand. It can't just be because the text does not say "by the way, for those who don't know, Wiktionary is a dictionary", can it? This would be dependent on readership. Some gaming magazine or whatever might refer to a video game that you and I have never heard of, without saying "by the way, this is a video game". [[User:Mihia|Mihia]] ([[User talk:Mihia|talk]]) 19:59, 30 August 2019 (UTC) : (outdent) A point of contrast is "Besides the renowned Wiktionary (http://www.wiktionary.org/), a multilingual, Web-based project to create a free content dictionary, available in over 150 languages and run by the Wikimedia foundation...": this clearly states what Wiktionary is, and therefore, does not imply that readers are supposed to know what Wiktionary is without introduction or description. A quotation that uses a brand name of a game in a game magazine would fail "The sources also must not be written ... about the type of product or service in general" in [[WT:BRAND]]. --[[User:Dan Polansky|Dan Polansky]] ([[User talk:Dan Polansky|talk]]) 06:39, 31 August 2019 (UTC) ::OK, I see. Well, as I say, I do not claim to understand "WT:BRAND", but I just assumed it would be stronger than allowing any mentions of something that assume readers will understand what it means. [[User:Mihia|Mihia]] ([[User talk:Mihia|talk]]) 23:36, 9 September 2019 (UTC) * '''Keep''': [[Citations:Wiktionary]] has quotations that AFAICS support [[WT:BRAND]]. Bringing this to RFV will bring nothing: we do have attesting quotations, and they need to be assessed as for meeting [[WT:BRAND]]. --[[User:Dan Polansky|Dan Polansky]] ([[User talk:Dan Polansky|talk]]) 07:24, 8 September 2019 (UTC) *'''Keep''': Per Dan Polansky (above). [[User:John Cross|John Cross]] ([[User talk:John Cross|talk]]) 06:28, 17 September 2019 (UTC) *'''Keep''': Per Dan Polansky, as well. [[User:Slayergames444|Слейер]][[User talk:Slayergames444| talk]] 20:58, 29 September 2019 (UTC) *'''Keep''': Pretty obvious, in my opinion. — [[User:LissanX|LissanX]] ([[User talk:LissanX|talk]]) 02:34, 25 October 2019 (UTC) * '''RFD kept'''. — [[User:Mnemosientje|Mnemosientje]] ([[User talk:Mnemosientje|t]] · [[Special:Contributions/Mnemosientje|c]]) 10:14, 8 January 2020 (UTC) *: Stricken out. --[[User:Dan Polansky|Dan Polansky]] ([[User talk:Dan Polansky|talk]]) 10:05, 15 February 2020 (UTC) {{archive-bottom}}

----- fr : [[dog]] * la femelle du chien s'appelle [[chienne]] et le petit [[chiot]] * the female of dog is called [[chienne]] and the young [[chiot]] '''Synonymes''' : Le meilleur ami de l'homme (man's best friend) '''Expressions''' * un temps de chien ("dog weather"): :fr: un temps très mauvais (pluie, vent ...) :en: bad weather, it refers when you don't want to go out, because it rains a lot, and is windy. :nl: [[hondenweer]] * chien de chasse: hunting dog * chien de garde: guard dog '''Remarques''' :fr: la racine latine ''can'' est utilisée aussi dans certains mots : canidé, canicule :en: in some words relating to dog, French used the root ''can'' as in ''canidé'', canicule
-----

revision.text:
== Coinage ==
{{ping|TagaSanPedroAko}} Where'd you source the theory that it was coined by Eusebio Daluz in 1915? I can find several sources using the word before 1915, the earliest is 1902 here: https://www.google.com.ph/books/edition/Ley_no_514_creando_la_junta_de_la_exposi/npODqNh1YwEC?hl=en&gbpv=1&dq=%22paaralan%22&pg=RA5-PA63&printsec=frontcover. [[User:Mar vin kaiser|Mar vin kaiser]] ([[User talk:Mar vin kaiser|talk]]) 07:08, 1 August 2023 (UTC)
:@[[User:Mar vin kaiser|Mar vin kaiser]] It has something to do with the etymologies for words like {{m|tl|bansa}} which has such similar claims. [[User:TagaSanPedroAko|TagaSanPedroAko]] ([[User talk:TagaSanPedroAko|talk]]) 07:10, 1 August 2023 (UTC) :: {{re|TagaSanPedroAko}} Can you source those claims? Because even the word "bansa", I can find in an article in 1907 herel, well before 1915 or 1910: https://www.google.com.ph/books/edition/The_Filipino_Teacher/30a0vpvmHHcC?hl=en&gbpv=1&dq=%22bansa%22+%22mga%22&pg=PP32&printsec=frontcover. --[[User:Mar vin kaiser|Mar vin kaiser]] ([[User talk:Mar vin kaiser|talk]]) 07:30, 1 August 2023 (UTC) :::@[[User:Mar vin kaiser|Mar vin kaiser]] You can just remove or replace them as appropriate. By the way, this and the likes of {{m|tl|bansa}} are all products of the Tagalista movement, of which Daluz is part of. [[User:TagaSanPedroAko|TagaSanPedroAko]] ([[User talk:TagaSanPedroAko|talk]]) 07:32, 1 August 2023 (UTC)
